Pictures<ref name=afi /> | released = {{Film date|df=yes|2004|05|23|[[Radio City Music Hall]]|2004|05|31|United Kingdom|2004|06|04|United States}} | runtime = 142 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 141:32--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/harry-potter-and-prisoner-azkaban-2 | title=''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban'' (PG) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=13 May 2004 | accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref> | country = {{Plain list| * United Kingdom * United States<ref>[http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b88b3cb7a Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)] Film Forever</ref> <!--Do not change this; see http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Harry_Potter_and_the_Order_of_the_Phoenix_%28film%29&oldid=126871681#What_makes_a_film_from_a_certain_country.3F for consensus --> }} | language = English | budget = $130 million<ref name="BOM"/> | gross = $796.7 million<ref name="BOM"/> }} '''''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban''''' is a 2004 [[fantasy film]]<!-- Do not add any other description here. --> directed by [[Alfonso Cuarón]] and distributed by [[Warner Bros.|Warner Bros. Pictures]].<ref name="BOM"/> It is based on [[J. K. Rowling]]'s [[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban|1999 novel of the same name]]. The film, which is the third instal<!--British English spells this word with one "l", not two -->ment in the [[Harry Potter (film series)|''Harry Potter'' film series]], was written by [[Steve Kloves]] and produced by [[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]] (director of the first two instalments), [[David Heyman]], and [[Mark Radcliffe (film producer)|Mark Radcliffe]]. The story follows [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]]'s third year at [[Hogwarts]] as he is informed that a prisoner named [[Sirius Black]] has escaped from [[Azkaban]] intending to kill him.
The film stars [[Daniel Radcliffe]] as Harry Potter, alongside [[Rupert Grint]] and [[Emma Watson]] as Harry's best friends [[Ron Weasley]] and [[Hermione Granger]]. It also features well-known actors in supporting roles, including [[Gary Oldman]] as Sirius Black, [[David Thewlis]] as Remus Lupin, [[Michael Gambon]] (in his debut in the role of [[Albus Dumbledore]]), [[Emma Thompson]] as Sybill Trelawney and [[Timothy Spall]] as Peter Pettigrew. It is the sequel to ''[[Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)|Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets]]'' and is followed by ''[[Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (film)|Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire]]''.
The film was released on 31 May 2004 in the United Kingdom and on 4 June 2004 in North America, as the first ''Harry Potter'' film released into [[IMAX]] theatres and to be using IMAX Technology. It was also the last ''Harry Potter'' film to be released on [[VHS]] in the [[U.S.]] The film was nominated for two [[Academy Awards]], [[Academy Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Music Score]] and [[Academy Award for Best Visual Effects|Best Visual Effects]] at the [[77th Academy Awards]] in 2005.
''Prisoner of Azkaban'' grossed a total of $796.7 million worldwide,<ref name="BOM"/> making it the [[2004 in film|second highest-grossing film of 2004]] and received praise for Cuarón's direction and the performances of the lead actors.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/harry_potter_and_the_prisoner_of_azkaban|title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban|publisher=}}</ref> It marked a notable change in the film series' tone and directing, and is considered by many critics and fans to be one of the best ''Harry Potter'' films.<ref name="usatoday.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2016/11/16/harry-potter-movies-ranked-fantastic-beasts/93907426/|title=A Definitive Ranking of the Harry Potter Movies|date=11 November 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="rottentomatoes.com">{{cite web|url=https://editorial.rottentomatoes.com/article/total-recall-harry-potter-movies/|title=All Harry Potter movies ranked worst to best by Tomatometer|date=13 November 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="seventeen.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.seventeen.com/celebrity/movies-tv/a25420/definitive-ranking-of-harry-potter-films/|title=Harry Potter Movies in Order of Ranking in the Series|date=14 February 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="collider.com">{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/best-harry-potter-movies-ranked-worst-to-best/#prisoner-of-azkaban|title='Harry Potter' Movies Ranked from Worst to Best|date=28 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="buzzfeed.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/mlg263/which-harry-potter-film-is-the-best-nvr5|title=Which "Harry Potter" Film Is The Best?|publisher=Buzzfeed|date=9 March 2015|first=Margo|last=Leigh|accessdate=12 November 2018}}</ref><ref name="mic.com">{{cite web|url=https://mic.com/articles/66473/alfonso-cuaron-how-the-gravity-director-saved-harry-potter|title=Alfonso Cuarón: How the 'Gravity' Director Saved Harry Potter|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="denofgeek.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/us/movies/harry-potter/255937/how-prisoner-of-azkaban-changed-the-harry-potter-franchise-young-adult-cinema-forever|title=How Prisoner of Azkaban Changed Young Adult Cinema Forever|publisher=}}</ref>
==Plot== <!-- Per WP:FILMPLOT, plot summaries for featured films are set between 400-700 words. This article also uses British English, so be sure to see WP:ENGVAR before inverting certain grammar, like "realise" for example. --> [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]] has been spending another dissatisfying summer with [[The Dursleys]]. When Harry's [[Aunt Marge]] insults his parents, he loses his temper and silently wills her to bloat up and float away. Fed up, Harry then flees the Dursleys with his luggage. The [[Knight Bus]] delivers Harry to the [[The Leaky Cauldron (pub)|Leaky Cauldron]], where he is pardoned by Minister of Magic [[Cornelius Fudge]] for using magic outside of [[Hogwarts]]. After reuniting with his best friends [[Ron Weasley]] and [[Hermione Granger]], Harry learns that [[Sirius Black]], a convicted supporter of the dark wizard [[Lord Voldemort]], has escaped [[Azkaban]] prison and intends to kill Harry.
The trio return to Hogwarts for the school year on the [[Hogwarts Express]], only for [[dementors]] to suddenly board the train, searching for Sirius. One enters the trio's compartment, causing Harry to pass out, but new [[Defence Against the Dark Arts]] teacher [[Professor Lupin]] repels the dementor with a [[Patronus Charm]]. At Hogwarts, headmaster [[Albus Dumbledore]] announces that dementors will be guarding the school while Sirius is at large. Hogwarts groundskeeper [[Rubeus Hagrid]] is announced as the new [[Magic in Harry Potter#Care of Magical Creatures|Care of Magical Creatures]] teacher; his first class goes awry when [[Draco Malfoy]] deliberately provokes the [[hippogriff]] [[Buckbeak]], who attacks him. Draco [[exaggerates]] his injury, and his father [[Lucius Malfoy]] later has Buckbeak [[Capital punishment|sentenced to death]].
[[The Fat Lady]]'s portrait, which guards the [[Gryffindor]] quarters, is found ruined and empty. Terrified and hiding in another painting, she tells Dumbledore that Sirius has entered the castle. During a stormy [[Quidditch]] match against [[Hufflepuff]], dementors attack Harry, causing him to fall off [[Nimbus 2000|his broomstick]]. At [[Hogsmeade]], Harry is shocked to learn that not only had Sirius been his father's best friend and apparently betrayed them to Voldemort, but is also Harry's godfather. Lupin privately teaches Harry to defend himself against dementors, using the Patronus Charm.
After Harry, Ron, and Hermione witness Buckbeak's execution, Ron's pet rat [[Scabbers]] bites him and escapes. When Ron gives chase, a large dog appears and drags both Ron and Scabbers into a hole at the [[Whomping Willow]]'s base. This leads the trio to an underground passage of the [[Shrieking Shack]], where they discover that the dog is actually Sirius, who is an [[Animagus]]. Lupin arrives and embraces Sirius as an old friend. He admits to being a werewolf, and explains that Sirius is innocent. Sirius was falsely accused of betraying the Potters to Voldemort, as well as murdering twelve Muggles and their mutual friend, [[Death Eater#Peter Pettigrew|Peter Pettigrew]]. It is revealed that Scabbers is actually Pettigrew, an Animagus who betrayed the Potters and committed the murders. After forcing him back into human form, Lupin and Sirius prepare to kill him, but Harry convinces them to turn Pettigrew over to the dementors.
As the group departs, the full moon rises and Lupin transforms into a [[werewolf]]. Sirius transforms into his dog form to fight him off. In the midst of the chaos, Pettigrew transforms back into a rat and escapes. Harry and Sirius are attacked by dementors, and Harry sees a figure in the distance save them by casting a powerful Patronus spell. He believes the mysterious figure is [[James Potter (character)|his deceased father]] before passing out. He awakens to discover that Sirius has been captured and sentenced to the [[Dementor's Kiss]].
Acting on Dumbledore's advice, Harry and Hermione travel back in time with Hermione's [[Time Turner]], and watch themselves and Ron repeat the night's events. They save Buckbeak from execution and witness the Dementors overpower Harry and Sirius. The present Harry realises that it was actually him who conjured the Patronus, and does so again. Harry and Hermione rescue Sirius, who escapes with Buckbeak. Exposed as a werewolf, Lupin resigns from teaching to prevent an uproar from parents. Sirius sends Harry a Firebolt broom, who happily takes it for a ride.
==Cast== {{further|List of Harry Potter cast members}} * [[Daniel Radcliffe]] as [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]], a 13-year-old British [[Magician (fantasy)|wizard]] famous for surviving his parents' murder at the hands of the evil dark wizard [[Lord Voldemort]] as an infant, who now enters his third year at [[Hogwarts|Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry]]. * [[Rupert Grint]] as [[Ron Weasley]], Harry's best friend at Hogwarts. * [[Emma Watson]] as [[Hermione Granger]], Harry's [[Fictional universe of Harry Potter#Muggle-born|Muggle-born]] best friend and the trio's brains. * [[Julie Christie]] as [[Madam Rosmerta]], the short-tempered landlady of the Three Broomsticks pub in [[Hogsmeade]]. * [[Robbie Coltrane]] as [[Rubeus Hagrid]], the [[gamekeeper]] and new [[Care of Magical Creatures]] teacher at Hogwarts. * [[Michael Gambon]] as [[Albus Dumbledore]], the [[head master|headmaster]] of Hogwarts and one of the greatest wizards of the age. Gambon assumed the role after [[Richard Harris]], who played Dumbledore in the previous two films, died on 25 October 2002, 3 weeks before the 2nd film's release.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/2362935.stm |title=Actor Richard Harris dies |accessdate=10 October 2007 |date=25 October 2002 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref> Despite his illness, Harris was determined to film his part, telling a visiting David Heyman not to recast the role.<ref name="heymanew">{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1123317_2,00.html |title=A Look Back |accessdate=10 October 2007 |date=28 October 2005 |first=Jeff |last=Jensen |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}</ref> Four months after Harris's death, Cuarón chose Gambon as his replacement.<ref name="heymanew"/><ref name="newsround">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/tv_film/newsid_2788000/2788225.stm |title=Dumbledore and Sirius cast for Azkaban |accessdate=10 October 2007 |date=21 February 2003 |publisher=Newsround}}</ref> Gambon was unconcerned with bettering or copying Harris, instead giving his own interpretation, putting on a slight Irish accent for the role,<ref name="castinterviews">{{cite video|date=2004 |title=Head to Shrunken Head |medium=DVD |people=[[Johnny Vaughan|Vaughan, Johnny]]; [[Lenny Henry|Henry, Lenny]] |publisher=Warner Bros. Pictures}}</ref> as well as completing his scenes in three weeks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.scotsman.com/topics.cfm?tid=3&id=613682004 |title=Olivier, Dumbledore and two broken ribs |accessdate=30 November 2007 |date=30 May 2004 |first=Siobhan |last=Synnot |work=[[The Scotsman]]}}</ref> Rumours of [[Ian McKellen]] being offered the role started to spread, but when asked he rejected the rumours and stated he had played a similar character in [[Gandalf]] of [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''The Lord of the Rings'' trilogy]]. He also stated it would have been inappropriate to take Harris's role, as the late actor had called McKellen a "dreadful" actor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mckellen.com/rumours/index.htm|title=Rumours|first=Keith|last=Stern/CompuWeb|website=www.mckellen.com}}</ref><ref>[http://www.mugglenet.com/mugglecast/transcripts/121.php MuggleNet – Mckellen on Harris] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910143245/http://www.mugglenet.com/mugglecast/transcripts/121.php |date=10 September 2011 }}</ref> Harris's family had expressed an interest in seeing Harris's close friend [[Peter O'Toole]] being chosen as his replacement.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.imdb.com/news/wenn/2003-01-09#celeb2 |title=Harris' Family Calling for O'Toole To Take on ''Harry Potter'' Role |accessdate=30 November 2007 |date=9 January 2003 |publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]]}}</ref> * [[Richard Griffiths]] as [[Vernon Dursley]], Harry's Muggle uncle. * [[Gary Oldman]] as [[Sirius Black]], Harry's infamous godfather, who escapes from the Wizarding prison [[Azkaban]] after serving twelve years there for being falsely accused of being the [[Death Eater]] who betrayed Harry's parents to Voldemort. Oldman accepted the part because he needed the money, as he had not taken on any major work in several years after deciding to spend more time with his children.<ref name="oldmancoventry">{{cite news|title=Coventry Evening Telegraph: GO: CINEMA: I CASHED IN ON HARRY POTTER! |date=28 May 2004 |work=[[Coventry Evening Telegraph]]}}</ref> He was "surprised by how difficult it was to pull off", comparing the role to [[Shakespearean]] dialogue.<ref name="oldmannewsround">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/tv_film/newsid_3758000/3758477.stm |title=Gary Oldman: Seriously Sirius |accessdate=30 November 2007 |date=28 May 2004 |publisher=Newsround}}</ref> * [[Alan Rickman]] as [[Severus Snape]], the [[Magic in Harry Potter#Potions|Potions]] teacher at Hogwarts and head of [[Slytherin]]. * [[Fiona Shaw]] as [[Petunia Dursley]], Harry's Muggle aunt. * [[Maggie Smith]] as [[Minerva McGonagall]], [[Deputy head teacher|Deputy Headmistress]] of Hogwarts, the [[Transfiguration (Harry Potter)|Transfiguration]] teacher at Hogwarts and head of [[Gryffindor]]. * [[Tom Felton]] as [[Draco Malfoy]], Harry's arch rival and a [[Slytherin]] house student. * [[Timothy Spall]] as [[Death Eater#Peter Pettigrew|Peter Pettigrew]], a friend of Harry's parents said to have been killed by Sirius Black, but was later revealed to have been the real Death Eater who betrayed Harry's parents to Voldemort. * [[David Thewlis]] as [[Remus Lupin]], the new [[Defence Against the Dark Arts]] teacher at Hogwarts and a [[werewolf]]. Thewlis, who had previously auditioned for the role of [[Quirinus Quirrell]] in ''[[Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone]]'', was Cuarón's first choice for the role of Professor Lupin. He accepted the role on advice from [[Ian Hart]], who was cast as Quirrell, and had told him that Professor Lupin was "the best part in the book."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moviehole.net/news/3764.html |title=Interview: David Thewlis |accessdate=28 August 2007 |date=9 June 2004 |first=Clint |last=Morris |publisher=Movie Hole |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070926225458/http://www.moviehole.net/news/3764.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 26 September 2007}}</ref> Thewlis had seen the first two films and had only read part of the first book, although after taking the role he read the third.<ref name="castinterviews"/> * [[Emma Thompson]] as [[Sybill Trelawney]], the [[Magic in Harry Potter#Divination|Divination]] teacher at Hogwarts. <!---Do Not Add Any More Cast--->
==Production==
===Development=== With ''Prisoner of Azkaban'', production of the ''Harry Potter'' films switched to an eighteen-month cycle, which producer [[David Heyman]] explained was "to give each [film] the time it required."<ref name="heymanew"/> [[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]], the director of the previous two films, decided not to return to helm the third instal<!--British English spells this word with one "l", not two-->ment as he "hadn't seen [his] own kids for supper in the week for about two and a half years."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/tv_film/newsid_2465000/2465225.stm |title=Chris Columbus COS: full interview |accessdate=10 October 2007 |date=13 November 2002 |publisher=Newsround}}</ref> Even so, he remained on as a producer alongside Heyman.<ref name="scifi">{{cite news|url=http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue372/interview.html |title=The creators of Harry Potter break out of character to discuss The Prisoner of Azkaban |accessdate=10 October 2007 |first=Lucinda |last=Dickey |publisher=Science Fiction Weekly |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070819163554/http://www.scifi.com/sfw/issue372/interview.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 19 August 2007}}</ref> [[Guillermo del Toro]] was approached to direct but considered the film "so bright and happy and full of light, that [he] wasn't interested."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2007/10/26/guillermo-game-for-harry-potter/ |title=Guillermo Game For ''Harry Potter'' |accessdate=26 October 2007 |date=26 October 2007 |first=Larry |last=Carroll |publisher=MTV |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027190511/http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2007/10/26/guillermo-game-for-harry-potter/ |archivedate=27 October 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Marc Forster]] turned down the film because he had made ''[[Finding Neverland (film)|Finding Neverland]]'' and did not want to direct child actors again. [[M. Night Shyamalan]] was considered to direct but turned it down because he was working on his own film, ''[[The Village (2004 film)|The Village]]''. Warner Bros. then composed a three-name short list for Columbus's replacement, which comprised [[Callie Khouri]], [[Kenneth Branagh]] (who played [[Gilderoy Lockhart]] in ''Chamber of Secrets'') and eventual selection [[Alfonso Cuarón]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,322583,00.html |title=Great Expectations |accessdate=10 October 2007 |first=Gary |last=Susman |date=19 July 2002 |work=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> Cuarón was initially nervous about accepting, as he had not read any of the books or seen the films. After reading the series, he changed his mind and signed on to direct,<ref name="cuaroninternewsround">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/tv_film/newsid_3758000/3758101.stm |title=Alfonso Cuaron: the man behind the magic |accessdate=10 October 2007 |date=24 May 2004 |publisher=Newsround}}</ref> as he had immediately connected to the story.<ref name="scifi"/> Cuarón's appointment pleased [[J. K. Rowling]] who loved his film ''[[Y Tu Mamá También]]'' and was impressed with his adaptation of ''[[A Little Princess (1995 film)|A Little Princess]]''.<ref name="rowling">{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2004-05-27-potter-movie-book_x.htm |title=New ''Potter'' movie sneaks in spoilers for upcoming books |accessdate=29 August 2007 |date=27 May 2004 |work=[[USA Today]] |first=Claudia |last=Puig}}</ref> Heyman found that "tonally and stylistically, [Cuarón] was the perfect fit."<ref name="heymanew"/> As his first exercise with the actors who portray the central trio, Cuarón assigned Radcliffe, Grint and Watson to write an autobiographical essay about their character, written in the first person, spanning birth to the discovery of the magical world, and including the character's emotional experience. Of Rupert Grint's essay, Cuarón recalls, "Rupert didn't deliver the essay. When I questioned why he didn't do it, he said, 'I'm Ron; Ron wouldn't do it.' So I said, 'Okay, you do understand your character.' That was the most important piece of acting work that we did on ''Prisoner of Azkaban'', because it was very clear that everything they put in those essays was going to be the pillars they were going to hold on to for the rest of the process."<ref name=castinterviews/><ref>McCabe, Bob. ''Harry Potter Page to Screen: The Complete Filmmaking Journey''. 2011. Harper Design. Page 102.</ref>
===Filming=== [[File:Loch Shiel - Glenfinnan bay (Scotland).jpg|thumb|right|[[Loch Shiel]], where scenes from ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' were filmed.]] Principal photography began on 24 February 2003,<ref name="newsround"/> at [[Warner Bros. Studios, Leavesden|Leavesden Film Studios]], and [[Wrap (filmmaking)|wrapped]] in October 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/preview/1808404333 |title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004) |accessdate=10 October 2007 |authorlink=Greg Dean Schmitz |first=Greg Dean |last=Schmitz |publisher=Yahoo! Movies}}</ref>
The third film was the first to extensively utilise real-life locations, as much of the first two films had been shot in the studio. Some sets for the film were built in [[Glen Coe]], Scotland, near the [[Clachaig Inn]]. The indoor sets, including ones built for the previous two films, are mainly in Leavesden Film Studios. The Hogwarts Lake was filmed from [[Loch Shiel]], [[Loch Eilt]] and [[Loch Morar]] in the Scottish Highlands. Incidentally, the [[Glenfinnan Viaduct|train bridge]], which was also featured in the ''[[Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (film)|Chamber of Secrets]]'', is opposite Loch Shiel and was used to film the sequences when the Dementor boarded the train. A small section of the triple-decker bus scene, where it weaves in between traffic, was filmed in North London's [[Palmers Green]]. Some parts were also filmed in and around [[Borough Market]] and [[Lambeth Bridge]] in London.
Hogwarts grew and expanded significantly with the third film. For the first time, the Hogwarts courtyard and bridge were seen. At the end of the bridge, rock monoliths were placed onto the hillside to evoke a [[Celtic people|Celtic]] feeling. The use of live-action also significantly changed the look of Hagrid's hut. In the first two films, it appeared at the end of a flat stretch, right in front of the Forbidden Forest. The third film utilised the more rugged Scottish locations to place Hagrid's hut at the bottom of a steep hillside. A large pumpkin patch was added behind the hut.
The [[Honeydukes]] set in this film is a [[redress]] of the set of [[Flourish & Blotts]] that was seen in ''Chamber of Secrets'', which, in turn, was a redress of the [[Ollivanders]] set from [[Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film)|the first film]].
Rowling allowed Cuarón to make minor changes to the book, on the condition that he stuck to the book's spirit.<ref name="cuaroninternewsround"/> She allowed him to place a [[sundial]] on Hogwarts' grounds, but rejected a graveyard, as that would play an important part in the then unreleased [[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince|sixth book]].<ref name="cuaroninternewsround"/> Rowling said she "got [[goose bumps|goosebumps]]" when she saw several moments in the film, as they inadvertently referred to events in the final two books, she stated "people are going to look back on the film and think that those were put in deliberately as clues."<ref name="rowling"/> When filming concluded, Cuarón found that it had "been the two sweetest years of my life," and expressed his interest in directing one of the sequels.<ref name="cuaroninternewsround"/>
===Effects=== Cuarón originally wanted to move away from CGI toward puppetry. He hired master underwater puppeteer Basil Twist to help, using puppets to study the potential movement of the Dementors.<ref name="heymanew"/> Once it became apparent that puppetry would be too expensive and unable to portray the specific elements of the Dementors, Cuarón turned to CGI; however, he and his team did use footage of Dementor puppets underwater as a basis for the flowing movements of the computer-generated Dementors.
The [[Knight Bus]] segment when Harry is being taken to [[The Leaky Cauldron (pub)|The Leaky Cauldron]] uses the technique known as [[bullet time]], popularised in ''[[The Matrix]]'' series of films. This segment takes humorous advantage of the [[magic (Harry Potter)|magic]] quality of the Harry Potter world by having the [[Muggle]] world go into bullet time while inside the Knight Bus, Harry, [[Stan Shunpike]] and [[Ernie Prang]] (and the talking shrunken head) keep moving in real time.
===Music=== [[File:John Williams tux.jpg|thumb|upright|John Williams]] {{Main|Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (soundtrack)}}
The Academy Award-nominated [[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (soundtrack)|score]] was the third and final score in the series to be composed and conducted by [[John Williams]]. It was released on CD on 25 May 2004. In general, this film's music is not as bright as that of the previous films, with distinct medieval influences in the instrumentation. One of the new themes, "Double Trouble," was written during production so that a children's choir could perform it in Hogwarts's Great Hall in one of the film's earlier scenes. The lyrics of "Double Trouble" are from a ritual performed by the Weïrd Sisters in Act 4, Scene 1 of Shakespeare's [[Macbeth]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Shakespeare|first=William|title=Macbeth|year=2009|publisher=Simon & Schuster Paperbacks|location=4.1.10–45|isbn=978-0-7434-7710-9|pages=119–121}}</ref> The film's trailer prominently features the cues "Anticipation" and "Progeny" by Brand X Music, a [[trailer music]] band.
==Differences from the book== <!-- This section should be integrated into the rest of the article --> ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' was, at the time of publication, the series' longest book. The increasing plot complexity necessitated a looser adaptation of the book's finer plot lines and back-story. The film opens with Harry using magic to light his wand in short bursts, whereas in the same scene in the book, he uses a torch/flashlight, as performing magic outside the wizard world is illegal for wizards under the age of seventeen. The connection between Harry's parents and the Marauder's Map is only briefly mentioned,<ref name="digitalspy">{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/movies/a64205/harry-potter-books-vs-films.html?page=3 |title=Harry Potter: books vs. films |publisher=[[Digital Spy]] |accessdate=10 October 2007 |date=9 July 2007 |last=Dadds |first=Kimberly |author2=Miriam Zendle}}</ref> as is [[Remus Lupin]]'s association to both the map and James Potter.<ref name="canmag">{{cite web|url=http://www.canmag.com/news/3/3/248 |title=Movie Rant |publisher=CanMag Magazine |accessdate=14 September 2007 |date=28 November 2004}}</ref> Additionally, it was never mentioned who the Marauders were or who the nicknames Moony, Wormtail, Padfoot, and Prongs referred to. Some [[Exposition (literary technique)|exposition]] was removed for dramatic effect: both the Shrieking Shack and Scabbers the rat are mentioned only very briefly in the film, while they receive a more thorough coverage in the novel.<ref name="digitalspy"/> Most of [[Sirius Black]]'s back story is also cut, with no mention of the manner of his escape from [[Azkaban]].<ref name="canmag"/> Only the first Quidditch game was kept in the film, due to its importance to the storyline; the second (Gryffindor/Ravenclaw) and third (Gryffindor/Slytherin) were cut. Thus, Harry receives the Firebolt at the film's end, while in the book he receives it anonymously at Christmas and it is confiscated for a few weeks to be checked for possible jinxes by Professor Flitwick and Madam Hooch.
On account of pace and time considerations, the film glosses over detailed descriptions of magical education. Only one Hippogriff, Buckbeak, is seen, and only Malfoy and Harry are seen interacting with the Hippogriff during [[Care of Magical Creatures]] lessons, and most other lessons, including all of [[Severus Snape|Snape's]] [[Potions Class|potions]] classes, were cut from the film.<ref name="digitalspy"/> The Fidelius Charm's complicated description is removed entirely from the film, with no explanation given of exactly how Black "betrayed" the Potters to [[Lord Voldemort]]. Many of this scene's lines are redistributed amongst [[Cornelius Fudge]] and [[Minerva McGonagall]]; in compensation, McGonagall's exposition of the Animagus transformation is instead given by Snape.<ref name="digitalspy"/>
In the film, where Harry and Hermione have travelled back in time and are hiding outside of Hagrid's hut, it is heavily implied that Dumbledore somehow knows that they are there, as he distracts the other characters at key moments or slows down the proceedings (such as by suggesting that he sign Buckbeak's execution order as well, then after Fudge agrees he says it will take some time as he has an extremely long name), which allows Harry and Hermione time to free Buckbeak unseen. In the book, Dumbledore merely comments that the executioner must sign the order, right before he is about to leave the cabin to execute Buckbeak.
The embryonic romantic connection between Ron and Hermione is more prominent in the film than the book; in response to criticism of the first two films for sacrificing character development for mystery and adventure, the emotional development of all three lead characters is given more attention in the third film.<ref name="digitalspy"/> That said, any mention of the beginnings of Harry's crush on [[Cho Chang]] is removed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,654023,00.html |title=Harry Situation |accessdate=10 October 2007 |date=17 June 2004 |work=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> Chang herself is not even seen until the next film. Harry's darker side is first glimpsed in this film, when Harry proclaims, "I hope he [Black] finds me. Cause when he does, I'm going to be ready. When he does, I'm going to kill him!"<ref name="digitalspy"/>
==Distribution==
===Marketing=== As with the series' previous instalments, ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' was a large merchandising opportunity.<ref>{{cite web|last=Watson|first=Julie|title=J.K. Rowling And Her Magical Cash Cow|url=https://www.forbes.com/2004/06/03/cx_jw_0603harrypotter.html|publisher=Frobes|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=3 June 2004}}</ref> The [[Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (video game)|video game version]], designed by [[EA UK]], was released 25 May 2004 in North America and 29 May 2004 in Europe. [[Mattel]] released film tie-ins that included the ''Harry Potter Championship Quidditch'' board game and character action figures.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bhatnagar|first=Parija|title=Hot in 2004: Movie toys & singing Barbie|url=http://money.cnn.com/2004/02/10/news/companies/new_toys/?cnn=yes|publisher=CNN Money|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=10 February 2004}}</ref> [[Lego]] also expanded on its previous merchandising for the first two films with the release of sets ranging from the Knight Bus to the Shrieking Shack.<ref>{{cite web|title=Toy Fair 2004: Harry Potter – LEGO®|url=http://www.rowm.com/news.php?gallery_id=1|publisher=Row M Enterprises, Inc.|accessdate=17 October 2012|year=2004}}</ref>
===Theatrical release=== ''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban'' held its New York premiere at [[Radio City Music Hall]] on 23 May 2004,<ref>{{cite web|title=Potter star mobbed at US premiere|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3741103.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=24 May 2004}}</ref> followed by its London premiere at [[Leicester Square]] on 30 May 2004.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wizard turn out for Harry Potter premiere|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-304817/Wizard-turn-Harry-Potter-premiere.html|publisher=Daily Mail|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=31 May 2004}}</ref> The film then opened in the United Kingdom on 31 May 2004 and on 4 June 2004 in the United States. It was the first film in the series to be released in both conventional and [[IMAX]] theatres.<ref>{{cite web|title=Potter 3 will be screened on IMAX|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/world/newsid_3333000/3333477.stm|publisher=CBBC Newsround|accessdate=17 October 2012|date=19 December 2003}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== Upon release, the film broke the record for biggest single day in the United Kingdom's box office history making £5.3 million on a Monday.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/tv_film/newsid_3769000/3769291.stm |title=Azkaban breaks box office record |accessdate=24 September 2007 |date=2 June 2004 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref> It went on to break records both with and without previews, making £23.9 million including previews<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.25thframe.co.uk/chartspagetemplate.php?source=ukwegross |title=Highest UK box office opening weekends |publisher=25th Frame |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref> and £9.3 million excluding them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sky-is-falling.co.uk/openingweekends-3dayonly-alltime.html |title=All time box office openings no previews |publisher=Sky is Falling |accessdate=24 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823220415/http://www.sky-is-falling.co.uk/openingweekends-3dayonly-alltime.html |archivedate=23 August 2007 }}</ref> ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' had the highest-opening weekend at the UK's box office, until ''[[Spectre (2015 film)|Spectre]]'' beat the record in 2015. It went on to make a total of £45.6 million in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.25thframe.co.uk/detail_page.php?rimage=harry_potter_and_the_prisoner_of_azkaban |title=Harry Potter and The Prisoner of Azkaban UK box office |publisher=25th Frame |accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref> The film made $93.7 million during its opening weekend in the United States and Canada at 3,855 theatres, achieving, at the time, the third biggest-opening weekend of all time.<ref name="Summer Bow">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=1387&p=.htm |title=Hotter ''Potter'': Summer Bow Yields Franchise High |accessdate=22 September 2007 |date=7 June 2004 |first=Brandon |last=Gray |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> This opening also broke ''[[Hulk (film)|Hulk]]''{{'}}s record ($62.1 million) for the highest-opening weekend for a film released in June.<ref name="Summer Bow" /> ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' held this record for five years until ''[[Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen]]'' topped it in 2009 with $108.9 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2601&p=.htm|title=Weekend Report: ‘Revenge of the Fallen' Rises with Optimal Debut |last=Gray|first=Brandon|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|date=29 June 2009|accessdate=3 November 2010}}</ref> The film was also No. 1 at the North American box office for two consecutive weekends.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2004&wknd=24&p=.htm |title=June 11-13, 2004 Weekend |accessdate=24 November 2013 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref>
''Prisoner of Azkaban'' made a total of $796.7 million worldwide,<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004) |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=harrypotter3.htm |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=5 February 2009}}</ref> which made it 2004's second-highest-grossing film worldwide behind ''[[Shrek 2]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=2004&p=.htm |title=2004 WORLDWIDE GROSSES |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=24 September 2007}}</ref> In the U.S. and Canada, it was only the year's sixth-highest-grossing film, making $249.5 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?yr=2004&p=.htm |title=2004 DOMESTIC GROSSES |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=24 September 2007}}</ref> Everywhere else in the world, however, it was the year's number one film, making $547 million compared to ''Shrek 2's'' $478.6 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/weekend/yearly/?yr=2004&p=.htm |title=OVERSEAS TOTAL YEARLY BOX OFFICE |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=24 September 2007}}</ref> Despite its successful box office run, ''Azkaban'' is the lowest-grossing ''Harry Potter'' film (all the others have grossed more than $800 million worldwide) and the second lowest-grossing film of ''J.K. Rowling's Wizarding World Series'' (behind ''[[Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald]]'').
===Critical response=== ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' is often regarded by critics and fans as one of the best films in the franchise.<ref name="usatoday.com"/><ref name="rottentomatoes.com"/><ref name="seventeen.com"/><ref name="collider.com"/><ref name="buzzfeed.com"/><ref name="mic.com"/><ref name="denofgeek.com"/> On the review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film has an approval rating of 91% based on 250 reviews, with an average rating of 7.9/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Under the assured direction of Alfonso Cuarón, ''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban'' triumphantly strikes a delicate balance between technical wizardry and complex storytelling."<ref name="Rotten Tomatoes">{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/harry_potter_and_the_prisoner_of_azkaban/ |title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004) |accessdate=13 September 2010 |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]] the film has a score of 82 out of 100, based on 40 critics, indicating "universal acclaim".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/video/titles/harrypotterandtheprisonerofazkaban?q=harry%20potter |title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban |accessdate=21 September 2007 |publisher=[[Metacritic]]}}</ref> On [[CinemaScore]], audiences gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="CinemaScore">{{cite web |url=https://www.cinemascore.com/publicsearch/index/title/ |title=CinemaScore |work=cinemascore.com }}</ref>
[[Mick LaSalle]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' lauded the film's more mature tone and said it was "darker, more complex, rooted in character."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/06/04/DDGOE6VR2118.DTL |title=It had to happen. Harry Potter's growing up. |accessdate=21 January 2011 |date=4 June 2004 |first=Mick |last=LaSalle |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]}}</ref> ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' called the film "a deeper, darker, visually arresting and more emotionally satisfying adaptation of the J.K. Rowling literary phenomenon," especially compared to the first two install<!--British English spells this word with one "l", not two-->ments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000521350 |title=Harry Potter: Prisoner of Azkaban |accessdate=21 September 2007 |date=28 May 2004 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070417220804/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000521350 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 17 April 2007}}</ref> [[Peter Travers]] of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave the film three-and-a-half out of four stars: "Not only is this dazzler by far the best and most thrilling of the three Harry Potter movies to date, it's a film that can stand on its own even if you never heard of author J.K. Rowling and her young wizard hero."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/6071754/review/6071752/harry_potter_and_the_prisoner_of_azkaban |title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban |accessdate=21 September 2007 |date=27 May 2004 |publisher=Newsround}}</ref> Stephanie Zacharek of ''[[Salon.com]]'' asserts it to be "one of the greatest fantasy films of all time."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://dir.salon.com/ent/movies/review/2004/06/03/prisoner_azkaban/ |title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban |accessdate=17 November 2010 |date=3 June 2004 |first=Stephanie |last=Zacharek |work=[[Salon.com]]}}</ref> Nicole Arthur of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' praised the film as "complex, frightening, [and] nuanced."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A12621-2004Jun3.html |title=Cuaron's Magic Touch |accessdate=22 January 2011 |date=4 June 2004 |first=Nicole |last=Arthur |work=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film three-and-a-half out of four stars, saying that the film was not quite as good as the first two, but still called it "delightful, amusing and sophisticated"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20040603/REVIEWS/406030301 |title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban |accessdate=23 September 2007 |date=3 June 2004 |first=Roger |last=Ebert |work=[[Chicago Sun Times]]}}</ref> Claudia Puig from ''[[USA Today]]'' found the film to be "a visual delight," and added that "Cuarón is not afraid to make a darker film and tackle painful emotions."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/reviews/2004-06-03-harry-potter-3_x.htm |title=''Azkaban'' wizard Cuaron casts an artful spell |accessdate=23 September 2007 |date=3 June 2004 |first=Claudia |last=Puig |work=[[USA Today]]}}</ref> while [[Richard Roeper]] called the film "a creative triumph."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://tvplex.go.com/buenavista/ebertandroeper/mp3/040607_harry_potter_azkaban.mp3 |title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban |accessdate=23 September 2007 |date=3 June 2004 |first=Richard |last=Roeper |publisher=[[At the Movies with Ebert & Roeper|Ebert & Roeper]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080307184111/http://tvplex.go.com/buenavista/ebertandroeper/mp3/040607_harry_potter_azkaban.mp3 |archivedate=7 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Sean Smith from ''[[Newsweek]]'' said: "''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' boasts a brand-new director and a bold new vision," he also called the film "moving," praising the performances by the three main leads,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/redirect.aspx?to=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/5040564/site/newsweek/&from=http://msnbc.msn.com/id/5040564/site/newsweek/ |title=The ''Harry Potter'' books have finally gotten the wondrous movie they deserve. ''The Prisoner of Azkaban'' boasts a brand-new director and a bold new vision. |accessdate=23 September 2007 |date=31 May 2004 |first=Sean |last=Smith |work=Newsweek |df=dmy-all }}{{dead link|date=October 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> while ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' praised the film for being more mature than its predecessors.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/entertainment/1086090938246590.xml |title=Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban |accessdate=24 September 2007 |date=3 June 2004 |first=Owen |last=Gleiberman |work=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref>
===Accolades=== ''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban'' was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Music Score]] ([[John Williams]]) and [[Academy Award for Best Visual Effects|Best Visual Effects]] at the [[77th Academy Awards]] held in 2005.<ref name=oscars>{{cite web|title=The 77th Academy Awards (2005) Nominees and Winners|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/legacy/ceremony/77th-winners.html|publisher=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|accessdate=16 October 2012}}</ref> This was the second film in the series to be nominated for an [[Academy Award|Oscar]].
The film also ranks at {{Abbr|No.|Number}} 471 in ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' magazine's 2008 list of the 500 greatest movies of all time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/500/6.asp|title=Empire's Greatest Movies of all Time|publisher=Empire|accessdate=13 December 2010}}</ref> [[IGN]] designated ''Prisoner of Azkaban'' as the fifth best fantasy film.<ref>{{cite web|first=Phil|last=Pirrello|url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/115/1159122p5.html|title=IGN's Top 25 Fantasy Films|publisher=IGN|date=4 April 2011|accessdate=5 April 2011}}</ref> Additionally, [[Moviefone]] designated the film as the tenth best of the decade. In 2011, the film was voted Film of the Decade at the First Light Awards by children aged 5–15.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12757207|title=Prisoner of Azkaban named film of the decade|publisher=BBC|date=16 March 2011|accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{short description|1929 animated film}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Hurdy Gurdy'' (film)}} <!-- Infoboxes are optional - please do not add one without discussing it on the talk page first. Thanks. --> [[File:Title card of Hurdy Gurdy (1929).png|thumb|289x289px|The title card of ''Hurdy Gurdy''.]] '''''Hurdy Gurdy''''' is a 1929<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> [[animated]] [[short film]] which is presented by [[Carl Laemmle]] and was produced by [[Walter Lantz]],<ref name=":0">{{Citation|last=Lance|first=Walter's|title=Hurdy Gurdy (1929)|date=2012-02-11|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fn_YP_c74Wo|volume=|pages=|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b7fbda4ef|title=Hurdy-gurdy (1930)|work=BFI|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> who he and his wife would go on to make [[Woody Woodpecker]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-03-19/local/me-5718_1_woody-woodpecker|title=Gracie Lantz Dies; Invented Woody Woodpecker|last=FOLKART|first=BURT A.|date=1992-03-19|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> The film, which is animated by R.C. Hamilton, Bill Nolan and Tom Palmer,<ref name=":0" /> features [[Oswald the Lucky Rabbit]],<ref name=":3" /> who is substituted for the [[organ grinder]]'s dancer,<ref name=":0" /> after the original one is comically swallowed up by Oswald's [[bubblegum]].<ref name=":0" />
The title is another name for the instrument (that instrument being a [[barrel organ]])<ref name=":0" /> which the street performer plays throughout the film,<ref name=":0" /> as the informal meaning of the term 'Hurdy Gurdy' is a "barrel organ".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/hurdy-gurdy|title=hurdy-gurdy {{!}} Definition of hurdy-gurdy in English by Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries {{!}} English|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref>
The film is recorded on [[Western Electric]] apparatus,<ref name=":0" /> which was an early [[sound-on-film]] recording system. This same system was also used on another Oswald short film entitled ''[[Permanent Wave (film)|Permanent Wave]]'',<ref name=":1">{{Citation|last=Rockin Ed|title=Permanent Wave [1929] Oswald The Lucky Rabbit|date=2009-12-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=edVvr3cDU1M|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> which was released in the same year.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
Copyrighted on 3 January 1930,<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://play.google.com/books/reader?id=M7vwCQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&output=reader&hl=en_GB&pg=GBS.PA352|title=The First Hollywood Sound Shorts, 1926–1931|last=Bradley|first=Edwin M.|date=2009-04-27|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9781476606842|language=en}}</ref> but released the year prior,<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/motionpicturenew40moti|title=Motion Picture News (Oct-Dec 1929)|last=Motion Picture News|first=Inc|date=1929|publisher=New York, Motion Picture News, Inc.|others=Media History Digital Library|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> the film was released by [[Universal Pictures]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> Thus, the film is part of the Universal series of Oswald The Lucky Rabbit films.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
==Plot== [[File:The street performer plays his barrel organ whilst Oswald is trying to escape.png|thumb|289x289px|The street performer plays his [[barrel organ]] (or hurdy-gurdy,) whilst Oswald is trying to escape.]] The film opens with a bear (who is the street performer) using a barrel organ, and a monkey dancing to the music made by it. They do this until Oswald throws his bubblegum onto the floor and the monkey steps on it. In an attempt to free himself, the monkey comically gets himself swallowed up by the gum. The street performer, who is angered by the events, grabs Oswald and drags him by the neck with a leach through whilst playing the barrel organ. He does this until he descends onto a street with a girl who is seen using her clothes and her washing line comically like a [[swing (seat)|swing]]. The girl think positively about the music, who attempts to give money to them. The street performer notices this and asks Oswald to get the money, by comically using a [[mouse trap]] in order to get up to her house. However, when Oswald gets into the house, he and the girl passionately kiss. The street performer, then tries to pull Oswald back with the leach. So Oswald free himself by comically takes off his head and removing the leach. He places the leach onto one of the legs of a [[hippo]]'s bathtub. Oswald then [[blows a raspberry]] in order to gather the street performer's attention. This angers the street performer, who pulls at the leach in order to retrieve Oswald. This comically sends the hippo's bathtub crashing through the window, and hitting the street performer on the ground. This makes the hippo scream, and comically run away with her legs in the bathtub. After that, The street performer sees both Oswald and the girl, and comically scales up a pipe in order to reach them. However, once the street performer is on top of the roof and tries to grab Oswald and the girl, Oswald and the girl both use a piece of clothing as a parachute, which catches the street perform off-guard, and also makes the street performer fall off the building and slam into the ground. After falling, the street performer realises that Oswald and the girl are stealing his barrel organ. So, in response, the street performer throws a brick at them both. The brick hits Oswald, who falls off the organ. The street performer then throws another brick. Oswald, then comically uses the organ to bat it away, like a [[baseball bat]]. He does this until one of the bricks hits the street performer on the head. This makes the street performer [[hallucinate]], with the buildings comically dancing in his hallucination. The street performer hallucinates until he collapses. Oswald and the girl both laugh at the events, and the film ends with them both kissing.<ref name=":0" />
==Characters== The film has three main characters, one of them is Oswald.<ref name=":0" /> Oswald is substituted as the dancer for the street performer,<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/motionpicturenew40moti|title=Motion Picture News (Oct-Dec 1929)|last=Motion Picture News|first=Inc|date=1929|publisher=New York, Motion Picture News, Inc.|others=Media History Digital Library|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> after the original one is comically swallowed up by bubblegum.<ref name=":0" /> Another character is the street performer, he plays the barrel organ<ref name=":4" /> throughout the film,<ref name=":0" /> and also fights with Oswald near the end of the film.<ref name=":0" /> That fight results in a brick being thrown at the street performer's head,<ref name=":0" />which makes him hallucinate and collapse at the end of the film.<ref name=":0" /> The other main character is the girl. She falls in love with Oswald and runs away with him at the end of the film.<ref name=":0" />
==Reception== ''Hurdy Gurdy'' was reviewed by the cinema magazines at that time.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" /><ref>''[[The Film Daily]]'', 22 December 1929</ref> ''[[The Motion Picture News]]'' said that the film includes ''Good Sound Cartoonantics'',<ref name=":4" /> and also said that the film developed "some good cartoon stunts".<ref name=":4" />
== References == <references />

{{multiple issues| {{notability|date=December 2013}} {{unreferenced|date=June 2012}} }} The '''Jumpin' Joe''' is a [[swing dance]] move adaptation, invented in 2007 in [[Ventura, California]]. It can be used as an adaptation on the [[Princess Dip]] or the [[Pretzel (dance)|Pretzel]]. It was meant for leads who may be shorter than their partner. Instead of struggling to swing their following partner's arm over her own head, he may jump as she does so, thus executing the Jumpin' Joe. == How It's Done (Princess Dip) == 1st, the lead would bounce his partner off his leg.
2nd, he would then spin his partner to return to the open-hand position.
3rd, as she spins to that position, he jumps to get his hand over her head.
4th, he lands and is returned to the open-hand position. == How It's Done (Pretzel) == After completing the Pretzel, 1st, the lead jumps to get his hand over head.
2nd, he lands and is returned to the open-hand position. [[Category:Swing dance moves]] [[Category:Swing dances]] {{dance-stub}}
