{{Multiple issues| {{cleanup reorganize|date=January 2016}} {{lead too short|date=January 2016}} }} [[Match fixing]] is when the outcome of a match in organized sports has been manipulated. The reason for fixing a match includes ensuring a certain team advances or gambling. Match fixing is seen as one of the biggest problems in organized sports. This page is a '''list of match fixing incidents'''.
==American football== *In 1998, four [[Northwestern University]] football players were indicted for lying to a federal [[grand jury]] when they testified they had not placed wagers on their own games in 1994. Only one player—[[Halfback (American football)|tailback]] [[Dennis Lundy]]—was accused of fixing the game. Lundy denied in front of the grand jury to intentionally [[fumble|fumbling]] on a play during a game against the [[University of Iowa]] in 1994. Federal prosecutors attested the fumble was intentional for the purposes of point-shaving.<ref>{{cite news |last=Dedman |first=Bill |title=COLLEGE FOOTBALL; 4 Are Indicted in Northwestern Football Scandal |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/04/sports/college-football-4-are-indicted-in-northwestern-football-scandal.html |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=December 4, 1998}}</ref> * 2009: On May 6, a federal grand jury in [[Detroit]] indicted six former [[University of Toledo]] athletes—three each from the school's football and basketball programs—on charges of conspiracy to commit sports bribery in relation to their alleged involvement in a point shaving scheme that ran from 2003 through 2006. It is believed to be the first major U.S. gambling case involving two sports at the same college.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncaa/news/story?id=4146980 |title=Six ex-players charged with conspiracy |first=Mike |last=Fish |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=2009-05-06 |accessdate=2009-05-12}}</ref> Since then, four former Toledo athletes, including at least one not named in the original indictments, have pleaded guilty on charges related to the scheme. One of these, former Rockets running back Quinton Broussard, admitted he had deliberately fumbled during the [[2005 GMAC Bowl]] against [[UTEP Miners football|UTEP]] (a game ultimately won 45–13 by Toledo) in exchange for $500, and had been paid to provide confidential team information to one of the orchestrators of the scheme.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/6895890/former-toledo-rockets-player-quinton-broussard-pleads-guilty-sports-bribery-investigation |title=Quinton Broussard pleads guilty |author=Associated Press |work=ESPN.com |date=August 25, 2011 |accessdate=August 26, 2011}}</ref>
==Association football== {{Further|Match fixing in association football}}
*In 1964, the great [[British betting scandal of 1964|British football betting scandal]] of the 1960s was uncovered. A betting ring organized by [[Jimmy Gauld]] and involving several Football League players had been fixing matches. The most famous incident involved three [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] players, including two England international players, who were subsequently banned from football for life and imprisoned after it was discovered they had bet against their team winning in a match against [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]]. A [[1915 British football betting scandal|similar scandal]] had occurred in 1915. *[[Totonero 1980|1980 Italian football scandal]] (''"Totonero"''): In May 1980, the largest match fixing scandal in the history of Italian football was uncovered by Italian [[Guardia di Finanza]], after the spalling of two Roman shopkeepers, Alvaro Trinca and Massimo Cruciani, who declared that some Italian football players sold the football-matches for money; implicating, among others, [[A.C. Milan|AC Milan]] and [[S.S. Lazio|Lazio]]. Teams were suspected of rigging games by selecting favorable referees, and even superstar Italian World Cup team goalkeeper [[Enrico Albertosi]] and future [[1982 FIFA World Cup]] winner Paolo Rossi banned with betting on football games.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-499301/UEFA-target-betting-mob.html UEFA target betting mob], ''[[Daily Mail]]'', 2 December 2007.</ref> Both clubs were forcibly relegated to [[Serie B]] and Milan's president, [[Felice Colombo]], received a life ban.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/4985738.stm Italian FA under emergency rule], [[BBC Sport]], 16 May 2006.</ref> * In February 1999 a [[Malaysia]]n-based betting syndicate was caught attempting to install a remote-control device to sabotage the floodlights at [[FA Premier League]] team [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]'s [[The Valley (London)|ground]] with the aid of a corrupt security officer. If the match had been abandoned after half-time, then the result and bets would have stood. Subsequent investigations showed that the gang had been responsible for previously unsuspected "floodlight failures" at [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham's]] [[Boleyn Ground|ground]] in November 1997, and again a month later at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace's]] [[Selhurst Park|ground]] during a home match of Palace's groundsharing tenant [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]].<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/422742.stm | work=BBC News | title=Football guard 'bribed for sabotage' | date=1999-08-17 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/426148.stm | work=BBC News | title=Bad bets and blown lights | date=1999-08-20 | accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> *The Italian Football Federation said in October 2000 it had found eight players guilty of match-fixing. Three were from Serie A side [[Atalanta Bergamo|Atalanta]] and the other five played for Serie B side [[Pistoiese]]. The players were [[Giacomo Banchelli]], [[Cristiano Doni]] and [[Sebastiano Siviglia]] (all Atalanta) and [[Alfredo Aglietti]], [[Massimiliano Allegri]], [[Daniele Amerini]], [[Gianluca Lillo]] and [[Girolamo Bizzarri]] (all Pistoiese). The charges related to an Italian Cup first round tie between the two sides in [[Bergamo]] on August 20, 2000 which ended 1–1. Atalanta scored at the end of the first half and Pistoiese equalised three minutes from full-time. Atalanta qualified for the second round. [[Snai]], which organises betting on Italian football, said later it had registered suspiciously heavy betting on the result and many of the bets were for a 1–0 halftime score and a full-time score of 1–1. *In 2004, Portuguese Police launched the operation [[Apito Dourado]] and named several Portuguese club presidents and football personalities as suspects of match fixing, including [[FC Porto]]'s chairman [[Jorge Nuno Pinto da Costa|Pinto da Costa]]. Some of the wiretaps used as proof, deemed unusable in court, can now be found on YouTube.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/330214-fc-porto-leaked-phone-taps-proof-major-corruption-scandal|title=FC Porto: Leaked Phone Taps Proof in Major Corruption Scandal|author=Josep Vernet-Riera|work=Bleacher Report|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XtqzgmhAOIk|title=Apito Dourado: António Araújo e Augusto Duarte|work=YouTube|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref> * In [[2004 in sports|June 2004]] in [[South Africa]], thirty-three people (including nineteen [[referee (association football)|referees]], club officials, a match commissioner and an official of the [[South African Football Association]]) were arrested on match-fixing charges.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/4396904.stm|title=Anti-sleaze probe collapses |publisher=News.bbc.co.uk|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref> * In the summer of 2004, [[Betfair]] provided evidence of race fixing to [[City of London Police]] that led to the arrest of [[jockey]] [[Kieren Fallon]] and fifteen others on race fixing charges. On 7 December 2007 the judge in the case ordered the jury to find Fallon not guilty on all charges. * [[Bundesliga scandal (2005)|2005 Bundesliga scandal]]: In [[2005 in sports|January 2005]], the [[German Football Association]] (DFB) and [[Germany|German]] prosecutors launched separate probes into charges that referee [[Robert Hoyzer]] bet on and fixed several matches that he worked, including a [[German Cup]] tie. Hoyzer later admitted to the allegations; it has been reported that he was involved with [[Croatia|Croat]] gambling syndicates. He also implicated other referees and players in the match fixing scheme. The first arrests in the Hoyzer investigation were made on January 28 in [[Berlin]], and Hoyzer himself was arrested on February 12 after new evidence apparently emerged to suggest that he had been involved in fixing more matches than he had admitted to. Hoyzer has been banned for life from football by the DFB. On March 10, a second referee, Dominik Marks, was arrested after being implicated in the scheme by Hoyzer. Still later (March 24), it was reported that Hoyzer had told investigators that the gambling ring he was involved with had access to [[UEFA]]'s referee assignments for international matches and [[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] and [[UEFA Cup]] fixtures several days before UEFA publicly announced them. Ultimately, Hoyzer was sentenced to serve 2 years and 5 months in prison. * In July 2005, [[Italy|Italian]] [[Serie B]] champions [[Genoa C.F.C.|Genoa]] was placed last in the division by the sporting justice, and therefore condemned to relegation in [[Lega Pro Prima Divisione|Serie C1]], after it was revealed that they bribed their opponents in the final match of the season, [[Venezia A.C.|Venezia]] to throw the match. His president Enrico Preziozi was banned for five years after being guilty by the sporting justice. Genoa won the match 3–2 and had apparently secured promotion to [[Serie A]]. *[[Brazilian football match-fixing scandal]]: In September 2005, a [[Brazil]]ian magazine revealed that two football referees, [[Edílson Pereira de Carvalho]] (a member of [[FIFA]]'s referee staff) and Paulo José Danelon, had accepted bribes to fix matches. Soon afterwards, sport authorities ordered the replaying of 11 matches in the country's top competition, the [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A|Campeonato Brasileiro]], that had been worked by Edílson. Both referees have been banned for life from football and face possible criminal charges. Brazilian supporters have taken to shout "Edílson" at a referee who they consider to have made a bad call against their team, in a reference to the scandal. *2008 ''The Fix'': Book by [[Declan Hill]] alleges that in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup]], the group game between Ghana and Italy, the round-of-16 game between Ghana and Brazil, and the Italy-Ukraine quarter-final were all fixed by Asian gambling syndicates to whom the final scores were known in advance.<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/sport/world-cup-matches-fixed-says-author/2008/08/31/1220121049179.html | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | title=World Cup matches fixed, says author | date=2008-09-01}}</ref> The [[German Football Federation]] (DFB) and [[German Football League]] (DFL) looked into claims made in a ''[[Der Spiegel]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,575586,00.html|title=Interview with Match-Fixing Investigator Declan Hill: 'I Am Sure the Game Was Manipulated'|author=SPIEGEL ONLINE, Hamburg, Germany|date=1 September 2008|work=SPIEGEL ONLINE|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref> interview with Hill that two [[Bundesliga]] matches were fixed by [[William Bee Wah Lim]] a fugitive with a 2004 conviction for match-fixing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerpro.com/the-fix/ |title=Declan Hill "The Fix" match fixing interview |publisher=SoccerPro.com |accessdate=2009-01-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131075803/http://soccerpro.com/the-fix/ |archivedate=January 31, 2009 }}</ref> *2008: On October 1, it was reported that a [[Spain|Spanish]] judge who headed an investigation against [[Russian Mafia]] figures uncovered information alleging that the mobsters may have attempted to fix the [[2007–08 UEFA Cup]] [[2007–08 UEFA Cup knockout stage#Semi-finals|semi-final]] between [[2008 UEFA Cup Final|eventual champion]] [[FC Zenit St. Petersburg|Zenit St. Petersburg]] and [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. Both clubs denied any knowledge of the alleged scheme.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=577977&sec=europe&&cc=5901 |title= Authorities to probe Zenit UEFA Cup "fix" claims |author=Reuters |publisher=''ESPNsoccernet.com'' | date=2008-10-01 |accessdate=2008-10-03}}</ref> Prosecutors in the German state of [[Bavaria]], home to Bayern, later announced that they did not have enough evidence to justify a full investigation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=581288&sec=europe&cc=5901 |title= No investigation into Zenit-Bayern fix |publisher=''ESPNsoccernet.com'' | date=2008-10-12 |accessdate=2008-10-12}}</ref> *2008: On October 4, suspicious online betting on the game between [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] and [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] led some to question the validity of the [[Football League]] match. Gamblers in Asia were said to have placed a large amount of money down during halftime, which raised concerns over the outcome.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/oct/16/derbycounty-norwichcity, FA launches match-fixing investigation into Norwich v Derby match], 16 October 2008, accessed 14 Match 2009</ref> The inquiry by [[The Football Association]] found no evidence that would suggest the match was fixed.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7766803.stm, Match-fixing inquiry closed by FA], 5 December 2008, accessed 14 March 2009.</ref> Derby County ended up winning the match 2–1. * In November 2009, German police arrested 17 people on [[2009 European football betting scandal|suspicion of fixing at least 200 soccer matches in 9 countries]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Arrests in Europe Over Soccer Fixing Investigation |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/21/sports/soccer/21fix.html |date=20 November 2009 |author1=Rob Hughes |author2=Eric Pfanner |lastauthoramp=yes|publisher=New York Times }}</ref> Among the suspected games were those from the top leagues of Austria, Bosnia, Croatia, Hungary, Slovenia, and Turkey, and games from the second highest leagues of Belgium, Germany, and Switzerland. Three contests from the Champions League were under investigation, and 12 from the Europa League. *In June 2011, trials started for people allegedly involved in fixing [[Finland|Finnish]] football matches. One team, [[Tampere United]] was indefinitely suspended from Finnish football for accepting payments from a person known for match-fixing.<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-13736085 |title=3 Finland football rocked by match-fixing scandal |work=[[BBC News]] |date=June 10, 2011 |accessdate=June 10, 2011}}</ref> * In July 2011, As part of a [[2011 Turkish sports corruption scandal|major match-fixing investigation]] by authorities in Turkey, nearly 60 people suspected to be involved with fixing games were detained by İstanbul Police Department Organized Crime Control Bureau and then arrested by the court. The case did not come to a conclusion yet and the teams that are being accused of match-fixing are participating in the Turkish league currently.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/jul/07/turkey-match-fixing|title=Turkish court charges 15 more in Fenerbahce match-fixing scandal|work=the Guardian|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref> *The [[Match fixing investigations of Norwegian Second Division]] saw Norway and Sweden arresting individuals in 2012, including players of [[Follo FK]] and [[Asker Fotball]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vg.no/sport/fotball/norsk/artikkel.php?artid=10047276|title=Ny Asker-spiller siktet i kampfiksingssaken |author=Stein-Erik Stormoen|work=VG|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smp.se/nyheter/vaxjo/vaxjobor-fast-i-harva-med-uppgjorda-fotbollsmatcher(3551503).gm|title=Växjöbor fast i härva med uppgjorda fotbollsmatcher|author1=Magnus Karlsson |author2=chefredaktör och ansvarig utgivare |work=Smålandsposten|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref> * [[Operation VETO]], a [[Europol]] investigation announced in 2013 that identified 380 fixed association football matches in 15 countries.<ref name='GuardJan'>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/feb/04/europol-investigation-football-matchfixing|title=Europol: investigators identify 380 fixed football matches|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''| accessdate=4 February 2013|location=London|date=4 February 2013}}</ref> * In [[2013 Lebanese match fixing scandal]] 22 Lebanese footballers were involved which led to a lifetime ban for [[Ramez Dayoub]]. * In December 2013, six people in Britain, including Blackburn forward [[DJ Campbell]], were arrested for [[2013 English match fixing scandal|allegedly fixing football games]]. The arrests were made by the [[National Crime Agency]] after release of a report from [[FederBet]], a Brussels-based gambling ''[[wikt:watchdog|watchdog]]'', an organization created by the online bookmakers to watch the ''flow'' of bets across Europe.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Hart, Simon|date=9 December 2013|title=DJ Campbell arrested in connection with football fixing|newspaper=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/10505343/DJ-Campbell-arrested-in-connection-with-football-fixing.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131209175217/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/10505343/DJ-Campbell-arrested-in-connection-with-football-fixing.html|archivedate=9 December 2013|deadurl=no|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=Lawton, Jerry|date=11 December 2013|title='Five top British footie games were rigged' claim match-fixing investigators|newspaper=Daily Star|location=Liverpool, England|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/latest-news/355214/Five-top-British-footie-games-were-rigged-claim-match-fixing-investigators}}</ref>
==Australian football== *In 1910, several members of the [[Carlton Football Club]] in the [[Victorian Football League]] were implicated in a match-fixing scandal. [[Alex Lang]] and [[Doug Fraser (Australian footballer)|Doug Fraser]] were suspended for 99 matches for their part in the scheme. [[Doug Gillespie]] was briefly dropped by Carlton, but re-joined the club before the [[Grand Final]] when the league report on the scandal exonerated him.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mackie |first1=Craig |title=Doug Fraser and the Bribery Scandal of 1910 |url=http://www.blueseum.org/tiki-read_article.php?articleId=100 |website=blueseum.org |accessdate=July 26, 2018}}</ref> *In 2009, [[Melbourne Football Club tanking scandal|allegations arose]] that the [[Melbourne Football Club]] had purposely lost matches to get a better pick in the upcoming [[Australian Football League draft]]—which in sports is known as 'tanking'. An investigation by the AFL exonerated Melbourne after finding no evidence they tanked.
==Badminton== *In 2008, [[China national badminton team|Chinese badminton]] coach [[Li Yongbo]] admitted to fixing a match during the [[2004 Summer Olympics]]. As a response, the [[Badminton World Federation]] created an integrity panel to investigate alleged match fixing incidents in badminton.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Suurballe |first1=Maria |title=Players take up the fight against match fixing in badminton |url=http://www.playthegame.org/news/news-articles/2008/players-take-up-the-fight-against-match-fixing-in-badminton/ |website=playthegame.com |accessdate=26 July 2018 |date=21 July 2008}}</ref> *During the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], several of the [[Badminton at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Women's doubles|Badminton women's doubles]] matches came under scrutiny from Olympic officials and the [[Badminton World Federation]] (BWF). Eight players were ejected from games for failing to used their “best efforts” to win their matches. There was no evidence that the games were thrown for gambling purposes, instead the teams deliberately under performed in early stage matches to get a better seeding in the [[round-robin tournament]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kelso |first1=Paul |title=Badminton pairs expelled from London 2012 Olympics after 'match-fixing' scandal |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/badminton/9443922/Badminton-pairs-expelled-from-London-2012-Olympics-after-match-fixing-scandal.html |accessdate=26 July 2018 |work=The Telegraph |date=1 August 2012}}</ref> *During the 2014 [[Japan Open (badminton)|Japan Open]], Danish Badminton Athletes Commission president [[Hans-Kristian Vittinghus]] was asked via [[Facebook]] by a man he met from prior tournaments if he would be interested in fixing matches. Vittinghus declined and later found out the same person approached [[Danes|Danish]] player [[Kim Astrup]] with the same offer. The two went to the [[Badminton World Federation]] (BWF) who then requested they re-engage the person in order to find out their identity.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man tried to fix Japan Open matches |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2015/04/09/more-sports/man-tried-fix-japan-open-matches/#.W1miXtVKgdU |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=The Japan Times |date=April 9, 2015}}</ref> *In 2018, the [[Badminton World Federation]] (BWF) issued suspensions of 15 and 20 years for [[Malaysian people|Malaysian]] players [[Tan Chun Seang]] and [[Zulfadli Zulkiffli]], respectively, for fixing matches during various 2013 tournaments. The BWF convinced an independent panel to investigate allegations made by an unnamed [[whistleblower]]. The investigation found that Zulkiffli had fixed at least four matches which accounted for 31 infractions under BWF rules.<ref>{{cite news |title=Match-fixing: Two Malaysian badminton players receive career-ending bans |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/badminton/43973618 |accessdate=26 July 2018 |work=BBC Sport |date=2 May 2018}}</ref>
==Baseball== *A game in September 1865 which resulted in a 23–11 victory for the [[Eckford of Brooklyn]] over the [[New York Mutuals]] was fixed according to confessions by those involved. Mutuals [[catcher (baseball)|catcher]] [[Bill Wansley]] was approached by gambler Kane McLoughlin to throw the game for $100. Wansley enlisted the help of the Mutuals [[third baseman]] [[Ed Duffy]] who agreed to participate if they included [[shortstop]] [[Tom Devyr]]. Wansley took the two players by [[wagon]] to the [[Hoboken Ferry]] where the payment was divided. Duffy and Devyr both received $30 each and Wansley kept $40 for himself. The fielding of those in on the fix—particularly Wansley's performance—was so poor that rumors of a fix began almost instantly. Wansley had so many [[passed ball]]s during the game that he was moved to [[right field]] in the seventh inning. [[Henry Chadwick (writer)|Henry Chadwick]] wrote about the game for the ''[[New York Clipper]]'' and defended Wansley against the fixing allegations. Mutuals players who were not in on the fix became suspicious of Wansley and accused him of "wilful and designated inattention". After a formal investigation, Wansley admitted to the fix and the three players were banned from organized baseball. Devyr was allowed to return in 1867 for a short time before two complaints from opposing teams were filed against the Mutuals. In December 1867 the baseball's [[Commissioner of Baseball|National Commission]] voted to reinstate Devyr. Duffy returned to the Mutuals in 1868, but was not reinstated by the National Commission, which led to one of the Mutuals opponents to file a complaint to void the games Duffy appeared in. The complaint was successful and the Mutuals were briefly expelled from organized baseball. The final convention of the amateur baseball National Commission was held on November 30, 1870. At the convention, Mutuals president John Wildly motioned to reinstate Wansley to good standing which was approved.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Ginsburg |first1=Daniel E. |title=The Fix Is In: A History of Baseball Gambling and Game Fixing Scandals |date=2004 |publisher=McFarland |location=North Carolina |isbn=0786419202 |page=7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lOjvggO19joC&source=gbs_navlinks_s |accessdate=July 23, 2018}}</ref> *On July 24, 1873 [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] [[Bob Ferguson (infielder)|Bob Ferguson]] declared a game between [[Baltimore Canaries]] and the [[New York Mutuals]] fixed by gamblers. Ferguson went into the stands to confront the gamblers following the game and then went back down to the field to confront players he believed were in on the fix. Two of the Mutuals players—[[John Hatfield (baseball)|John Hatfield]] and [[Nat Hicks]]—began accusing each other of being in on the fix. Hicks eventually grabbed a [[baseball bat]] and struck Ferguson in the arm which caused it to break. Ferguson, who was also a player as well as an umpire, was unable to play for one year because of the injury. No actions were taken against Hicks or any other player.<ref>Ginsburg, pp. 20–21</ref> *In 1877, four players for the [[Louisville Grays]] were banned from organized baseball for [[1877 Louisville Grays scandal|throwing games]]. ''[[Louisville Courier-Journal]]'' sports writer [[John Haldeman]], whose father [[Walter Haldeman]] owned the team, became suspicious of the play of the four members of the Grays and began writing in his columns that he believed the players were purposefully losing. His columns led to a formal investigation and four players—[[Jim Devlin]], [[George Hall (baseball)|George Hall]], [[Al Nichols]] and [[Bill Craver]]—were banned from organized professional baseball for life. Carver's involvement in the plot is debated by baseball historians including Bob Bailey for the [[Society of American Baseball Research]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bailey |first1=Bob |title=August 20, 1877: Gray outcomes for 'Louisville Four' |url=https://sabr.org/gamesproj/game/august-20-1877-gray-outcomes-louisville-four |website=SABR.org |publisher=Society for American Baseball Research |accessdate=July 23, 2018}}</ref> *In 1882, due to his associations with gamblers, [[National League]] [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] [[Dick Higham]] was [[List of people banned from Major League Baseball|banned from organized baseball for life]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Batesel |first1=Paul |title=Players and Teams of the National Association, 1871–1875 |date=2012 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=0786490764 |page=72}}</ref> The information was uncovered by [[private investigator]]s hired by owners of the [[Detroit Wolverines]], who suspected Higham of fixing games.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Laing |first1=Jeffrey Michael |title=The Haymakers, Unions and Trojans of Troy, New York: Big-Time Baseball in the Collar City, 1860–1883 |date=2015 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=1476619654 |page=128}}</ref> *In 1908, [[National League]] [[umpire (baseball)|umpires]] [[Jim Johnstone (umpire)|Jim Johnstone]] and [[Bill Klem]] reported to the league office that they were approached before a make-up game between the [[Chicago Cubs]] and the [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] and offered money to fix the game. The make-up game was on account of a baserunning mistake by [[Fred Merkle]] known as "[[Merkle's Boner]]".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Anderson |first1=David W. |title=Jim Johnstone |url=https://sabr.org/bioproj/person/e51cb9e8 |website=SABR.org |publisher=Society for American Baseball Research |accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> *An [[American League]] game on September 25, 1919 between the [[Detroit Tigers]] and [[Cleveland Indians]] was fixed according to letters ascertained by league president [[Ban Johnson]] in 1926. The letters were between Detroit [[outfielder]] [[Ty Cobb]] and Cleveland outfielder [[Smokey Joe Wood]]. They were sold to Johnson by [[pitcher (baseball)|pitcher]] [[Dutch Leonard (left-handed pitcher)|Dutch Leonard]] who was one of the four players in on the fix along with Cobb, Wood and Cleveland [[player-manager]] [[Tris Speaker]]. According to Leonard, Cobb suggested the players place bets on the game which they had already agreed to fix. Cobb denied placing any bets, but did confess to being involved in the fix. According to a retrospective of events by the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' in 1989, Leonard went to Johnson with the letters in 1926 after he became embittered at Cobb and Wood whom he felt had a hand in ending his career early. Johnson initially turned Leonard away and he went to Detroit owner [[Frank Navin]] with the letters. Navin advised Johnson to make a payment to Leonard to keep the letters from going public. Johnson then agreed to pay Leonard $20,000 for the letters. Following the 1926 season, Johnson called a secret meeting with Cobb and Speaker, who were the managers of their respective teams. Johnson laid out the facts and advised the men to resign their positions as managers, which both did. Cobb and Speaker both retired from playing in 1928 and neither took another managerial job.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Holtzman |first1=Jerome |title=Cobb And Speaker Got Themselves Into A Real Fix |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-05-21/sports/8902030567_1_betting-dutch-leonard-ty-cobb |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=Chicago Tribune |date=May 21, 1989}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] broke the story on December 21, 1926.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cobb and Speaker Named in Baseball Expose |url=http://nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn84024315/1926-12-22/ed-1/seq-1/#date1=01%2F01%2F1910&index=1&date2=12%2F31%2F1950&searchType=advanced&SearchType=prox10&sequence=0&words=Fixed+fixed+fixing+Game+game&proxdistance=10&to_year=1950&rows=20&ortext=&from_year=1910&proxtext=fixed+game&phrasetext=&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=1 |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=The Republican-Journal |date=December 22, 1926 |location=Ogdensburg, New York |page=1|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> *In 1919, gamblers bribed several members of the [[Chicago White Sox]] to throw the [[World Series]]. This became known as the [[Black Sox Scandal]] and was recounted in book and movie form as ''[[Eight Men Out]]''. *Following the 1919 [[Pacific Coast League]] (PCL) season, [[first baseman]] [[Babe Borton]] alleged that as a member of the pennant winning [[Vernon Tigers]], he was party to pay-offs to all other PCL teams to ensure they would lose to Vernon. Borton alleged that every member of the Tigers pooled their money to make the pay-offs. Nate Raymond of [[Seattle, Washington]] was responsible for the payments according to Borton. [[Seattle Indians]] first baseman Rod Murphy alleged that Raymond offered him a $2,000 bribe during the 1920 season and confided that during the 1919 season he won $50,000 from gambling on fixed PCL games. Ultimately no player was charged with fixing games because there were no state statutes that were violated. The PCL banned several players for life, but some like [[Bill Rumler]] was reinstated after several years.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Figone |first1=Al |title=The 1919 Pacific Coast League Fixing Scandal: The "Black Sox" Had Nothing on Babe Borton |journal=North American Society for Sport History |date=1996 |url=http://library.la84.org/SportsLibrary/NASSH_Proceedings/NP1996/NP1996zh.pdf |accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> *On September 27, 1924, before a game between the [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] and the [[Philadelphia Phillies]], Giants backup [[outfielder]] [[Jimmy O'Connell (baseball)|Jimmy O'Connell]] approached Phillies [[shortstop]] [[Heinie Sand]] with a $500 bribe for to throw the game. If the Giants beat the Phillies it would have clinched them the [[National League]] [[National League pennant|pennant]] and a trip to the [[World Series]]. Sand rejected the offer and reported the incident which made its way up to the [[Commissioner of Baseball]] [[Kenesaw Mountain Landis]]. O'Connell confessed that he did attempt to bribe Sand, but contended Giants coach [[Cozy Dolan]] had put him up to it. Landis suspended O'Connell and Dolan from [[List of people banned from Major League Baseball|organized baseball for life]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Snelling |first1=Dennis |title=The Greatest Minor League: A History of the Pacific Coast League, 1903–1957 |date=2011 |publisher=McFarland |isbn=0786488034 |page=104}}</ref> *On June 5, 1947, [[Minor League Baseball|National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues]] president [[George Trautman]] banned [[Western Association]] [[outfielder]] [[Marion McElreath]] for attempting to bribe an opposing player to fix a game on May 4. 1947.<ref>{{cite book |last1=McKenna |first1=Brian |title=Early Exits: The Premature Endings of Baseball Careers |date=2007 |publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=0810858584 |page=29}}</ref> *In 1947, a report by [[Commissioner of Baseball|National Commission]] president [[William G. Bramham]] found that five players in the [[Evangeline League]], a [[minor league baseball|minor league]] based in [[Louisiana]], fixed several playoff games in 1946 for gambling purposes. For their role in the alleged plot, the five players—Bill Thomas, Lanny Pecou, Alvin W. Kaiser, Paul Fugit and Don Vettorel—were banned from [[professional baseball]] for life. An investigation of the alleged actions of the five players by [[Society for American Baseball Research]] writer George W. Hilton found little proof that there was any match-fixing. One of the accused players, Bill Thomas, [[pitcher|pitched]] a perfect 5–0 record in the playoffs. Hilton conducted an interview with an unnamed player in the Evangeline League who claimed he was approached to be a part of the fixing scheme, but declined. The unnamed player contended that the plot failed, which was highlighted by one instance where a player who was in on the fix tried to strike out but made contact with the ball for a [[double (baseball)|double]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hilton |first1=George W. |title=The Evangeline League Scandal of 1946 |journal=SABR Research Archive |date=<!-- undated --> |url=http://research.sabr.org/journals/archive/45-brj-1982/357-the-evangeline-league-scandal-of-1946 |accessdate=July 23, 2018}}</ref> *Between 1969 and 1971, a series of events known as [[The Black Mist Scandal (Japanese baseball)|The Black Mist Scandal]] rocked [[Nippon Professional Baseball]] (NPB) in [[Japan]]. It was revealed that several NPB players had been paid off to fix games for gamblers. Ten players were banned from the NPB for life with several other players receiving penalties ranging from salary cuts to suspensions. *In 1978, [[outfielder]] [[Bárbaro Garbey]] was banned from [[Cuban baseball league system|Cuban baseball]] for his part in match-fixing. He defected from [[Cuba]] to the [[United States]] in 1980 and later that year signed a contract with the [[Detroit Tigers]] to join their [[Minor League Baseball|minor league]] organization. The match-fixing incidents were revealed for the first time in the American press on May 22, 1983 by the ''[[Miami Herald]]''. In an interview with Garbey, ''Herald'' writer Peter Richmond brought up match-fixing allegations and Garbey admitted to playing a part in the scheme. Garbey was allowed to continue his minor league career, but the Tigers were prevented from calling him up by ruling of the [[Commissioner of Baseball|National Commission]] president [[John H. Johnson (baseball)|John H. Johnson]]. The ruling was lifted in 1984 and the Tigers called Garbey up from the minors.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hill |first1=Doug |title=Barbaro Garbey |url=https://sabr.org/bioproj/person/a7b39deb |website=sabr.org |publisher=Society for American Baseball Research |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref><ref>McKenna, pp 27</ref> Garbey later returned to Cuba and became a [[manager (baseball)|manager]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bjarkman |first1=Peter C. |title=Cuban League |url=https://sabr.org/bioproj/topic/cuban-league |website=sabr.org |publisher=Society for American Baseball Research |accessdate=July 26, 2018}}</ref> *In 1982, the ten members of the [[Cuban national baseball team]] who participated in [[1982 Central American and Caribbean Games|that year's Central American and Caribbean Games]] were arrested and sentenced to between two and four years in prison for fixing games.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rodríguez |first1=Michel I. |title=Peligrosidad Social vs. Béisbol |url=https://desdemipalcodefanatico.wordpress.com/archivo/peligrosidad-social-vs-beisbol/|website=desdemipalcodefanatico.wordpress.com |publisher=Desde Mi Palco De Fanatico |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |language=Spenish |date=January 10, 2013}}</ref> *In 1997, 22 players in the [[Chinese Professional Baseball League]] were sentenced to between seven and 30 months in prison for match-fixing.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chang |first1=Rich |title=More baseball players questioned |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2005/07/29/2003265476 |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=Taipei Times |date=July 29, 2005 |page=2}}</ref> So many of the members of [[China Times Eagles]] were involved in the plot that the team fielded mostly [[rookie]]s in that season's championship series.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wang |first1=Chao-yu |title=Fixing puts future of baseball at serious risk |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2005/07/31/2003265814 |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=Taipei Times |date=July 31, 2005 |page=8}}</ref> *In 2005, [[Yunlin County]], [[Taiwan]] prosecutor Wei-yu Hsu announced indictments of 16 baseball players, book makers and others involved in fixing [[professional baseball]] games. Five of the 16 people were players in the [[Chinese Professional Baseball League]] and one of them was a coach. Hsu named [[Macoto Cobras]] coach [[Sheng-fong Tsai]] and [[La New Bears]] [[catcher (baseball)|catcher]] [[Chao-ying Chen]] as being the orchestrators of the fixings. One of the instances included in the indictment was evidence that La New Bears [[pitcher (baseball)|pitcher]] [[Long-shui Tai]] was paid by Chen to throw a game on July 14, 2005. Chen confessed to investigators that he accepted a payment of [[NT$]]600,000 to throw the game.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chang |first1=Rich |title=Players, gangsters face charges in baseball fix |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2005/08/25/2003269044 |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=Taipei Times |date=August 25, 2005}}</ref> *In 2008, three players were suspended indefinitely from the [[Chinese Professional Baseball League]] (CPBL) for match-fixing. Prosecutors said evidence of the fixing came to light after police detained six members of [[dmedia T-REX]] and four people identified as [[bookmaker]]s. T-Rex executive director [[Shih Chien-hsin]] confessed to police that hatched the plan with people identified as "gangsters" by the ''[[Taipei Times]]''. The three players banned from the CBPL were [[catcher (baseball)|catcher]] [[Chen Ker-fan]], [[center fielder]] [[Chen Yuan-chia]] and pitcher [[Cory Bailey]]. Chen Ker-fan and Chen Yuan-chia, who were both from [[Taiwan]], were arrested and released on [[NT$]]50,000 in bail each. Bailey, who is an [[Americans|American]] national and previously played in [[Major League Baseball]], was arrested and released on a NT$100,000 bond.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chuang |first1=Jimmy |title=Baseball players suspended in match-fixing probe |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2008/10/10/2003425459 |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=Taipei Times |date=October 10, 2008}}</ref> In 2008, Taiwan's [[Criminal Investigation Bureau]] looked into a total of 102 illegal betting allegations in the CPBL, which involved a total of 222 suspects.<ref name="latimes16">{{cite news |last1=Jennings |first1=Ralph |title=Baseball was nearly dead in Taiwan after a major cheating scandal. Here’s how it made a comeback |url=http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-taiwan-baseball-snap-story.html |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=Los Angeles Times |date=October 18, 2016 |location=Los Angeles, California}}</ref> *In 2009, another match-fixing scandal hit the [[Chinese Professional Baseball League]] (CPBL). Following the season, allegations arose that the [[Chinatrust Brothers|Brother Elephants]]—one of Taiwan's most popular baseball clubs—had accepted money to lose during that year's [[Taiwan Series]] against the [[Uni-President 7-11 Lions]].<ref name="NYTimes09">{{cite news |last1=Adams |first1=Jonathan |title=The Taint of Scandal in Taiwan's Pro League |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/29/sports/baseball/29iht-BETS.html |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=October 28, 2009 |location=New York}}</ref> By the end of a prosecutor's investigation, 23 Elephants players had been named as being in on the fix, including pitcher [[Chin-hui Tsao]], who was the first Taiwanese pitcher to play in [[Major League Baseball]].<ref name="latimes16"/><ref name="NYTimes09"/> Tsao denies having any involvement with match-fixings.<ref name="NYTimes09"/> In 2009, [[President of the Republic of China]] [[Ying-jeou Ma]] convinced a meeting to address the systemic match fixing problems in the CPBL. Penalties for match-fixing were re-written to mirror the laws governing lotteries, which called for up to 10 years in prison for fraud.<ref name="latimes16"/> *During the [[2012 Major League Baseball season|2012]] and [[2013 Major League Baseball season]]s, allegations were made by gamber Kris Barr that he was in on fixing [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] games with [[pitcher (baseball)|pitcher]] [[Jeff Locke (baseball)|Jeff Locke]]. After an investigation, it was found that Barr had no contact with Locke relating to fixing games. Instead, Barr felt slighted by Locke—whom he knew from youth baseball—and created an elaborate story to damage his reputation. The [[Center for Investigative Reporting]] and ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' released the details of the events on August 18, 2014 which included reporting on the aggressive tactics of the MLB investigators led by retired [[New York Police Department]] officer Rick Burnham. Locke recalled that the MLB investigators told him that they had proof that he was in on fixing games and pressured him to confess, in spite of his pleas of innocence and the fact the investigators presented no proof.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Lance |last2=Tuohy |first2=Brian |title=How a small-time handicapper concocted a wild MLB game-fixing tale |url=https://www.si.com/mlb/2014/08/12/mlb-gambling-facebook-game-fixing |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=Sports Illustrated |agency=Center for Investigative Reporting |date=August 12, 2014}}</ref> *In 2016, [[South Korea]]n police released information about an alleged match-fixing scheme in the [[Korea Baseball Organization]] (KBO) dating back to 2014 that involved 21 people—three of whom played in the KBO. Pitchers [[Chang-sik Yoo]] and [[Sung-min Lee]] were named by police in the probe and one player was identified only by his surname 'Kim'.<ref>{{cite news |title=Korean Baseball Organization Facing Match Fixing Scandal; Over the past few years, the Korean Baseball Organization has garnered a lot more attention, as several players have come over to the MLB. This time, the attention that the league is getting is far less positive |url=https://www.foxsports.com/mlb/story/korean-baseball-organization-facing-match-fixing-scandal-110816 |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=Fox Sports |publisher=Fox Sports Interactive Media, LLC |date=June 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Sang-Hun |first1=Choe |title=South Korea Charges 21 With Match Fixing |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/08/sports/baseball/south-korea-match-fixing.html |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=November 7, 2016}}</ref>
==Basketball== *In 1946, [[Brooklyn College]] players admitted to conspiring to fix an upcoming game set to take place on January 31, 1945 against [[Akron University]]. Brooklyn players Henry Rosen and Harvey Stemmer were convicted of "conspiracy to cheat and defraud" on May 9, 1945. Stemmer was immediately sentenced to one year in the state penitentiary and a $500 fine. Rosen was sentenced on May 16 and in spite of the jury's request that the [[World War II]] veteran receive leniency Judge Louis Goldstein also sentenced Rosen to one year in the state penitentiary. His sentence was reduced to 15 to 30 months in state prison by Manhattan's General Sessions Court Judge Gould Schurman, Jr. a month later.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Goldstein |first1=Joe |title=Rumblings: The Brooklyn five |url=https://www.espn.com/classic/s/basketball_scandals_rumblings.html |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=ESPN.com |publisher=ESPN |date=November 19, 2003}}</ref> *In 1951, in the [[CCNY point shaving scandal]], District Attorney [[Frank Hogan]] indicted college basketball players for [[point shaving]] from four New York schools, including CCNY, [[Manhattan Jaspers basketball|Manhattan College]], [[NYU Violets men's basketball|New York University]] and [[LIU Brooklyn Blackbirds men's basketball|Long Island University]]. *In 1961, Joseph Hacken and Aaron Wagman were arrested in [[New York (state)|New York]] for arranging fixes of college basketball games. The fixed games according to New York [[District Attorney]] [[Frank Hogan]] were the Connecticut–Colgate game in [[Hamilton, New York]] and the Seton Hall–Dayton game at [[Madison Square Garden]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tax |first1=Jeremiah |title=The facts about the fixes |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1961/03/27/580227/the-facts-about-the-fixes |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=Sports Illustrated |date=March 27, 1961}}</ref> *In 1978, mobsters connected with the New York [[Lucchese crime family]], among them [[Henry Hill]] and [[Jimmy Burke (gangster)|Jimmy Burke]], organized a [[Boston College basketball point shaving scandal of 1978–79|point shaving scheme]] with key members of the [[Boston College]] [[Boston College Eagles men's basketball|basketball team]]. *In 1981, the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) announced they were looking into allegations of point shaving during three [[Big Eight Conference]] basketball games in February 1981. The [[United Press International]] reported that the three games being investigated were [[Kansas Jayhawks men's basketball|Kansas]] at [[Missouri Tigers men's basketball|Missouri]] on February 9, [[Oklahoma State Cowboys basketball|Oklahoma State]] at [[Colorado Buffaloes men's basketball|Colorado]] on February 14 and [[Nebraska Cornhuskers men's basketball|Nebraska]] at [[Missouri Tigers men's basketball|Missouri]] on February 21.<ref>{{cite news |title=Untitled |work=United Press International |date=April 14, 1981 }}</ref> No further allegations were made and nothing materialized from the FBI investigation. *In 1985, [[Tulane Green Wave men's basketball|Tulane University]] (New Orleans, Louisiana) players were involved in a point shaving scheme that led to [[Death penalty (NCAA)#Tulane|the disbandment of the program for four years]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Vangilder |first=Lenny |title=A Sad Anniversary: 25 Years Since Tulane Basketball's Point Shaving Scandal |url=http://www.sportsnola.com/sports/tulane/360519-a-sad-anniversary-25-years-since-tulane-basketballs-point-shaving-scandal.html |work=SportsNOLA |accessdate=6 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220023029/http://www.sportsnola.com/sports/tulane/360519-a-sad-anniversary-25-years-since-tulane-basketballs-point-shaving-scandal.html |archivedate=20 December 2013 |df= }}</ref> * In 1994, a comprehensive [[point shaving]] scheme organized by campus bookmaker [[Benny Silman]] and involving players from the [[Arizona State University]] [[Arizona State Sun Devils men's basketball|men's basketball team]] was uncovered with the assistance of [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] bookmakers, who grew suspicious over repeated large wagers being made against Arizona State.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/basketball/college/news/1998/06/30/asu_shaving/|title=Sports Illustrated: Silman gets 46 months for his part in ASU point-shaving scandal|publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com|accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref> *In April 2011, a U.S. federal grand jury in [[San Diego]] indicted a group of 10 individuals on charges of running a point shaving scheme affecting an as yet-undetermined number of college basketball games. Three of the accused have ties to the [[University of San Diego]]'s [[San Diego Toreros men's basketball|men's basketball team]]—one was the team's all-time leader in points and assists; another was a former player; and the third was a former assistant. Games at the [[University of California, Riverside]], where the second indicted player also played, were also mentioned as potentially being fixed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/apr/11/ten-indicted-college-basketball-points-fixing-sche/ |title=3 with USD ties indicted in bribery scheme |first=Debbi |last=Baker |author2=Moran, Greg |work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |date=April 11, 2011 |accessdate=April 12, 2011}}</ref> *In 2015, [[South Korea]]n police announced they were investigating alleged match fixing in the [[Korean Basketball League]], which involved a total of 11 players with at least one of them suspected of intentionally missing shots in an attempt to change the outcome of a game. The other players in the investigation had allegedly placed wagers on [[online gambling|sports betting website]]s.<ref>{{cite news |title=S Korea basketball players in match-fixing probe |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/09/korea-basketball-players-match-fixing-probe-150908064734671.html |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=Al Jazeera |date=September 8, 2015}}</ref> * On 22 January 2016, ESPN Reporter Brian Windhorst, broke the news on [[Bomani Jones]]'s show,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/espnradio/play?id=14628263|title=Brian Windhorst, NBA|work=ESPN.com}}</ref> that players from the [[NBA]] team the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] threw a regular season game against the [[Portland Trail Blazers]] in an attempt to get head coach [[David Blatt]] fired.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bayareasportsguy.com/windhorst-to-spite-blatt-cavs-boycotted-game-in-portland-after-losing-to-warriors/|title=Bay Area Sports Guy – Windhorst: To spite Blatt, Cavs "boycotted" game in Portland after losing to Warriors|publisher=bayareasportsguy.com}}</ref> *In 2017, eight members of the [[Siliwangi Bandung]] in the [[Indonesian Basketball League]] were expelled from the league for fixing at least four games. Danny Kosasih, chairman of the [[Indonesian Basketball Association]], said he received proof of the match fixing through recorded audio conversations of the players involved.<ref>{{cite news |title=Indonesia basketball players fixed games ‘to pay their salaries|url=https://www.thestar.com.my/sport/basketball/2017/11/23/indonesia-basketball-players-fixed-games-to-pay-their-salaries/ |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=Star.com.my |agency=American Free Press |date=November 23, 2017}}</ref> *In 2017, allegations arose that the [[Red Bull]] [[Korea]] amateur [[3x3 (basketball)|three-on-three basketball]] tournament was fixed for the [[South Korea]]n team, 'Project X', to win. According to the allegations published in ''[[The Korea Times]]'', the other South Korean teams competing in the tournament colluded to make sure Project X beat out the foreign teams. The ''Times'' alleged this was possible because of the tournament's rules that added the team's points up to determine the winner instead of a traditional [[elimination tournament]]. The opposing South Korean teams let Project X run up the score during their contests to game the overall outcome of the tournament, according to the ''Times''. Red Bull Korea denied having any part in the alleged scheme.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Woo |first1=Ji-won |title=Match-fixing scandal taints Red Bull basketball tournament |url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/nation/2017/08/177_235176.html |accessdate=July 23, 2018 |work=The Korea Times |date=August 22, 2017}}</ref>
==Boxing== [[File:Tommy Burns 1912.jpg|thumb|[[Heavyweight]] [[boxer]] [[Arthur Pelkey]] alleged his manager [[Tommy Burns (boxer)|Tommy Burns]] ''(pictured)'' arranged a fixed fight on March 26, 1913.]]
{{expand section|date=July 2018}} *In September 1913, [[heavyweight boxer]] [[Arthur Pelkey]], who was the reigning [[World White Heavyweight Championship|World White Heavyweight Champion]], submitted a signed letter to Roscoe Fawcett, sports editor of ''[[The Oregonian]]'', which stated that he was involved in a fixed match on March 26, 1913 in [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]], [[Canada]] under the direction of his manager [[Tommy Burns (boxer)|Tommy Burns]]. Pelkey further alleged that Burns made the heavyweight sign over fifty percent of his earnings when he was in police custody awaiting a determination by the [[coroner]] if he was responsible for the in-ring death of his opponent [[Luther McCarty]] on May 24, 1913. McCarty's death was eventually ruled unrelated to that match and Pelkey continued his boxing career with Burns as his manager.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Fawcett |first1=Roscoe |title=Pelkey confesses to 'fake' match; Heavyweight claimant bares details of 'frame up' with Tommy Burns |url=https://oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn83025138/1913-09-10/ed-1/seq-8/ |accessdate=July 24, 2018 |work=Morning Oregonian |date=September 10, 1913 |page=8}}</ref> *On September 22, 1922 at the [[Vélodrome Buffalo and Stade Buffalo|Vélodrome Buffalo]] in [[Paris]], [[France]], the reigning [[World Light Heavyweight Championship|World Light Heavyweight Champion]] [[Georges Carpentier]] took on [[Battling Siki]] in what was supposed to be a fixed fight, according to Siki. During the fight, Carpentier went back on a previous arrangement to not hurt Siki, although it is debated by [[Smithsonian.com]] writer Gilbert King whether or not Carpentier was in on the fix or if it was arranged by someone from his [[Cornerman|corner]] without his knowledge. Siki then decided to fight Carpenter without letting up, but was eventually disqualified in a controversial decision by referee M. Henri Bernstein. Later the decision was reversed and Siki was crowned the World Light Heavyweight Champion.<ref>{{cite news |last1=King |first1=Gilbert |title=The Fight that Wouldn’t Stay Fixed; How an apparent misunderstanding led to a brawl that turned into a donnybrook that became a legend |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/the-fight-that-wouldnt-stay-fixed-126493491/ |accessdate=July 25, 2018 |work=Smithsonian.com |publisher=Smithsonian Institution |date=November 15, 2012}}</ref> *In 1954, it was reported by ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' that [[welterweight]] [[boxer]] Vince Martinez was offered $20,000 to lose to Carmine Fiore in a televised match on October 29 at [[Madison Square Garden]] in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Martinez ended up winning the bout and was escorted to [[New Jersey]] for his safety by members of [[District Attorney]] [[Frank Hogan|Frank Hogan's]] staff in a prearranged deal for information on the people who tried to fix the match.<ref>{{cite news |title=Martinez and the $20,000 fix that failed |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1954/11/22/549296/martinez--the-20000-fix-that-failed |accessdate=July 25, 2018 |work=Sports Illustrated |date=November 22, 1954}}</ref> *In 1955, [[California Governor]] [[Goodwin J. Knight]] created an investigative committee to look into allegations of match fixing in boxing. The following year, the committee convened a hearing where it was revealed they had evidence that [[boxing promoter]] [[Babe McCoy]] had fixed seven fights dating back to 1950.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Murray |first1=James |title=The fix in California |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1956/04/02/597322/the-fix-in-california |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=Sports Illustrated |date=April 2, 1956}}</ref> *In 1993, ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' reported that several fights arranged by [[boxing promoter]] Rick "Elvis" Parker were fixed according to boxer Sonny Barch, who claimed he was approached by Parker and told to lose the fight against [[Randall "Tex" Cobb]] scheduled on September 15, 1993. Cobb knocked out Barch in the first-round. Barch also claimed to have knowledge of another fix which occurred on the same card as his fight between [[American football|football]] player turned boxer [[Mark Gastineau]] and Rick Hoard. In that match, Gastineau won by a [[technical knockout]] in the first round.<ref>{{cite news |title=Gastineau, Cobb Fights Fixed, SI Report Says |url=https://newsok.com/article/2443458/gastineau-cobb-fights-fixed-si-report-says |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=The Oklahoman |date=September 29, 1993}}</ref> Cobb denied the claims and sued ''Sports Illustrated'' for libel. He was awarded $10.7 million by a federal jury in 1999.<ref>{{cite news |title=Boxer Is Awarded Damages From Time |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/06/14/business/boxer-is-awarded-damages-from-time.html |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=The New York Times |agency=Associated Press |date=June 14, 1999}}</ref> The verdict was reversed on appeal on January 31, 2002.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sports Illustrated wins appeal over boxing story verdict |url=https://www.rcfp.org/browse-media-law-resources/news/sports-illustrated-wins-appeal-over-boxing-story-verdict |website=rcfp.org |publisher=Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |date=January 31, 2002}}</ref> *At the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], a match result was overturned and the referee was expelled from the tournament after a very controversial decision which included a boxer winning the match despite having been knocked down five times in one round, in violation of amateur boxing regulations. Under AIBA rules, both the mandatory eight count and three knockdown rule are in effect.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/olympics/19088420 | title=Olympics boxing: Japan win appeal after controversial loss | publisher=BBC | date= 2 August 2012}}</ref> Eleven months earlier, BBC reported on a possible bribery attempt, which could be related.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-15020658 | title=Allegations of deal to fix 2012 Olympic boxing medals | publisher=BBC | date=11 September 2011}}</ref> *During the [[2016 Summer Olympics]], ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' reported that several boxing judges and referees were dismissed by the [[International Boxing Association (amateur)|International Boxing Association]] due to suspect decisions.<ref>{{cite news |title=Olympics; Boxing judges, referees sent home after controversial decisions |url=https://www.si.com/olympics/2016/08/17/boxing-judges-referees-sent-home-after-controversial-decisions |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=Sports Illustrated |date=August 17, 2016}}</ref>
==Cricket== [[File:Sreesanth 1.jpg|thumb|[[India]]n [[cricket (sport)|cricketer]] [[S. Sreesanth]] received a lifetime ban in 2013 for his part a match-fixing scheme.]] * In 1979, [[Somerset County Cricket Club|Somerset]] deliberately declared their innings in their [[Benson & Hedges Cup]] one-day match against [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]] closed after only one over was completed. This plan was not motivated by gambling, but was instead meant to manipulate tie-breaking rules for Somerset's benefit and assure qualification for the quarterfinals of the tournament. Although the plan was not against the letter of the rules, it was widely condemned by both media and cricket officials, and Somerset was expelled from that year's tournament in response. For more details, see [[Worcestershire v Somerset, 1979]]. * In 2000 the [[Delhi]] police intercepted a conversation between a blacklisted bookie and the [[South African cricket team|South Africa]]n [[cricket]] captain [[Hansie Cronje]] in which they learnt that Cronje accepted money to throw matches. The South African government refused to allow any of its players to face the Indian investigation unit, which opened up a can of worms. A court of inquiry was set up and Cronje admitted to throwing matches. He was immediately banned from all cricket. He also named [[Saleem Malik]] ([[Pakistani cricket team|Pakistan]]), [[Mohammed Azharuddin]] and [[Ajay Jadeja]] ([[Indian cricket team|India]]). Jadeja was banned for 4 years. They too were banned from all cricket. As a kingpin, Cronje exposed the dark side of betting, however with his untimely death in 2002 most of his sources also have escaped law enforcement agencies. Two South African cricketers, [[Herschelle Gibbs]] and [[Nicky Boje]], are also wanted by the Delhi police for their role in the match fixing saga. A few years before in 1998, [[Australian cricket team|Australia]]n players [[Mark Waugh]] and [[Shane Warne]] were fined for revealing information about the 'weather' to [[John the bookmaker controversy|a bookmaker]]. *The fourth [[Test cricket|Test]] of [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan's]] [[Pakistani cricket team in England in 2010|summer 2010 cricket tour]] of England was alleged to have contained several incidents of [[spot fixing]], involving members of the Pakistan team deliberately bowling [[no-ball]]s at specific points to facilitate the potential defrauding of bookmakers.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/england/8953215.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=England beat Pakistan in tarnished Test to win series |date=29 August 2010 |accessdate=3 August 2010}}</ref> * In [[Indian Premier League]] in 2013, [[S. Sreesanth]] and 2 other players were banned for fixing in the match for incidents committed during bowling.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sreesanth: Former India bowler banned for life for spot-fixing|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/24076409|work=BBC|accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref> * In the [[2012 Champions League T20]] in South Africa, New Zealand cricketer [[Lou Vincent]] was reported to have fixed matches for [[Auckland Aces]] in the qualifiers against English side [[Hampshire Cricket Club]], and again in the main stage against reigning Indian champions [[Kolkata Knight Riders]].
==Esports== [[File:Shinhan3winner.png|thumb|[[Esports]] player [[Ma Jae-Yoon]] was implicated in a 2010 [[Starcraft]] match-fixing scandal]] *In 2010, several professional Starcraft players were suspected of being involved in illegal match fixing, with two people arrested and about seven gamers investigated, with two renowned gamers, [[Ma Jae-Yoon]] and By.CrocuS were confirmed as working as a broker between the bettors and the gamers.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/tech/2010/05/129_64247.html|title=StarCraft Rigging Scandal Hits e-Sports Industry|date=2009-05-06 |work=[[The Korea Times]] |accessdate=2010-05-12}}</ref> * In January 2015, 6 ''[[Counter-Strike: Global Offensive]]'' players and a team owner were banned due to the [[IBuyPower and NetcodeGuides match fixing scandal]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Integrity and Fair Play|url=http://blog.counter-strike.net/index.php/2015/01/11261/|publisher=''[[Valve Corporation]]''|accessdate=26 January 2015|date=26 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title= A Follow Up to Integrity and Fair Play|url=http://blog.counter-strike.net/index.php/2016/01/13442/|publisher=''[[Valve Corporation]]''|accessdate=5 January 2016|date=5 January 2016}}</ref> * In June 2013, a ''[[Dota 2]]'' pro player Alexey "Solo" Berezin was caught match fixing during a match against ZRage in SLTV Star Ladder Season VI as RoX.Kis. The match had no bearing on their standings since both teams could no longer qualify for the LAN finals. Solo bet $100 against his team and proceed to intentionally throw the game and supposedly won $322 from it. As a result of being caught Solo received a lifetime ban from Starladder (later reduced to one year<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gosugamers.net/dota2/news/24589-solo-s-ban-reduced-to-one-year|title=Solo's Starladder ban reduced to one year|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en}}</ref> and was later removed from the team<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.joindota.com/en/news/10165-solo-out-of-rox-kis|title=Solo out of RoX.KiS « News|last=freaks4u.com|first=Freaks 4U Gaming GmbH,|website=joinDOTA.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref>), a three-year ban for the other players, and one-year ban for the organization.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.joindota.com/en/news/9989-update-rox-kis-issues-statement|title=Update: roX.KIS issues statement « News|last=freaks4u.com|first=Freaks 4U Gaming GmbH,|website=joinDOTA.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/dota/roxkis-team-banned-starladder-dota-2-tournament-betting-fraud|title=roX.KIS team banned from Starladder Dota 2 tournament over allegations of betting fraud|work=PCGamesN|access-date=2017-11-14}}</ref> * In October 2014, ''[[Dota 2]]'' Pro players Kok Yi "ddz" Liong and Fua Hsien "Lance" Wan were both found guilty of match fixing during the match against CSW on Synergy SEA as Arrow Gaming as it has been found that both their girlfriends have betted expensive quality items against their team where they proceed to intentionally throw the match. Arrow Gaming repeatedly tried to deny this but conclusive evidence eventually proves this fact and as a result, the teams have been removed from Synergy SEA and disqualified from other tournaments such as Summit 2. Both ddz and Lance were removed from the Arrow Gaming and the rest of the team disbanded one day later.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.joindota.com/en/news/22341-arrow-involved-in-sea-matchfixing|title=Arrow involved in SEA matchfixing « News|last=freaks4u.com|first=Freaks 4U Gaming GmbH,|website=joinDOTA.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gosugamers.net/dota2/news/28858-ddz-admits-involvement-in-matchfixing-says-evidence-faked-by-arrow-s-manager|title=DDZ admits involvement in matchfixing, says evidence faked by Arrow's manager|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en}}</ref>
==Handball== *In 2012, several [[French people|French]] [[handball]] players from the [[Montpellier Handball|Montpellier]] club were arrested on allegations they fixed matches.<ref>{{cite news |title=Montpellier players arrested over match-fixing |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-handball-montpellier/montpellier-players-arrested-over-match-fixing-idUSBRE88T0EN20120930?feedType=RSSandamp;feedName=sportsNews |accessdate=26 July 2018 |work=Reuters |date=30 September 2012}}</ref> In June 2015, the French government pressed charges against the alleged Montpellier fixers who included [[Olympic medal]]ist [[Nikola Karabatic]], his brother [[Luka Karabatic]] and six others Montpellier players. Prosecutors alleged Montpellier, who had already sealed the French handball championship, purposefully lost to [[Cesson Rennes MHB|Cesson]] in May 2012. French authorities were tipped off to the alleged fix when discovering that over 100,000 [[euros]] in bets had been placed on the low-stakes game that prosecutors contend should have only garnered a few thousand euros in wagers. In July 2015, the 16 people indicted by French authorities for their part in the match fixing scandal—including the Karabatic brothers—were found guilty. Nikola Karabatic was fined 10,000 euros and the largest fine on 30,000 euros went to [[Mladen Bojinovic]]. None of the people were given jail sentences, despite the prosecutors request.<ref>{{cite news |title=French handball star Karabatic found guilty of match-fixing |url=http://en.rfi.fr/sports/20150711-french-handball-player-found-guilty-match-fixing |accessdate=26 July 2018 |work=Radio France Internationale |date=11 July 2015}}</ref> The Karabatic brothers appealed the decision and in 2017, but lost and a new ruling made by the Disciplinary Committee of the [[French Handball Federation]] required Nikola Karabatic to sit out six games and Luka Karabatic to sit out two.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Szekeres |first1=Ibolya |title=New verdict in match-fixing case of Karabatic brothers |url=http://timeoutmag.com/2017/11/12/new-verdict-in-match-fixing-case-of-karabatic-brothers/ |website=timeoutmag.com |publisher=Time Out Magazine |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |date=November 12, 2017}}</ref>
==Motorsport== [[File:Nelson Piquet 2009 Australia.jpg|thumb|[[Nelson Piquet Jr.]] admitted to [[Renault Formula One crash controversy|intentionally wrecking his Formula One car]] during a 2008 race.]] *In September 2009, [[Formula 1]] driver [[Nelson Piquet Jr.]] admitted to have intentionally wrecked his race-car during the [[2008 Singapore Grand Prix]] due to team orders. It gave an advantage to his teammate [[Fernando Alonso]] who went on to win the race. Following a lawsuit by the [[Renault F1|Renault Formula 1 team]] against the Piquet family, a judge ruled in Piquet's favor due to overwhelming evidence against the team; fining the Renault Formula 1 team millions, lliquidating various employees, banning the team from Formula 1 for 2 years (on suspended sentence) and various key members of Renault Formula 1 team being banned for life (which was later appealed). :{{Further|Renault Formula One crash controversy}} *In the [[NASCAR]] [[Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series|Cup Series]], the [[2013 Federated Auto Parts 400]] was scandalized by [[2013 Federated Auto Parts 400#Race manipulation controversy|extensive manipulation of the race results]] by three teams—[[Michael Waltrip Racing]], [[Penske Racing]], and [[Front Row Motorsports]]—in an attempt to ensure that MWR and Penske drivers would earn places in the [[NASCAR playoffs|Chase for the Sprint Cup]]. When the manipulation was discovered, NASCAR imposed unprecedented penalties that knocked [[Martin Truex Jr.]], one of the intended beneficiaries, out of the Chase, and also gave [[Jeff Gordon]], an unwitting victim of the manipulation, a 13th place in the normally 12-driver Chase.
==Snooker== :{{main|List of snooker players investigated for match-fixing}} *In 2009, [[snooker]] player [[Stephen Maguire]] acknowledged through his management company that police had questioned him about allegations of match-fixing at the [[UK Championship]] in [[Telford, England]] on December 15, 2008.<ref>{{cite news |title=Stephen Maguire interviewed by Police Fraud Squad |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/snooker/5190915/Stephen-Maguire-interviewed-by-Police-Fraud-Squad.html |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=The Telegraph |date=20 April 2009}}</ref> *In 2010, allegations were made by the [[United Kingdom|British]] newspaper ''[[News of the World]]'' that [[snooker]] champion [[John Higgins (snooker player)|John Higgins]] had accepted a [[Pound sterling|£]]261,000 bribe from undercover reporters in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]] to throw frames. Higgins denied the bribery and match fixing allegations.<ref>{{cite news |title=Snooker: World No.1 defiant amid bribe claims |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/SPORT/05/03/snooker.higgins.bribe.allegations/index.html |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=CNN.com |date=May 4, 2010}}</ref> During an investigation of the events, the [[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] (WPBSA) placed Higgins on suspension.<ref>{{cite news |title=John Higgins suspended in snooker bribe probe |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk/8656905.stm |accessdate=26 July 2018 |work=BBC News |date=2 May 2010}}</ref> Later that year, a WPBSA endorsed tribunal found Higgins guilty of accepting a bribe but found no evidence of match fixing.<ref>{{cite news |title=John Higgins cleared of match-fixing claims |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/other_sports/snooker/8973869.stm |accessdate=26 July 2018 |work=BBC Sport |date=8 September 2010}}</ref> *In 2016, [[Ireland|Irish]] snooker player [[Leo Fernandez]] was banned from the sport for 15 months by the [[World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association]] (WPBSA) for manipulating part of a match. While it was not a full manipulation of the match's outcome, Fernandez had contact with people that placed a [[prop bet]] which said he would chose to shoot the first foul shot of the game. Fernandez did opt to take first foul shot, thus making the bet successful. The WPBSA ruled that was a violation of their corruption bylaws.<ref>{{cite news |title=Leo Fernandez handed 15-month ban after admitting corruption charge |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/snooker/36722680 |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=BBC Sport |date=6 July 2016}}</ref>
==Tennis== *In 2007, [[France|French]] tennis player [[Arnaud Clément]] claimed he was offered a bribe to fix a match, which he turned down, but added, "I won't say where or under what circumstances". Clément feared divulging more details on the bribe would have negative consequences on his career.<ref>{{cite news |title=I turned down bribe to fix match, says Clement |url=https://www.smh.com.au/sport/tennis/i-turned-down-bribe-to-fix-match-says-clement-20071031-gdrh2h.html |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |agency=Associated Press |date=31 October 2007}}</ref> *In 2008, the [[Association of Tennis Professionals]] cleared [[Russia]]n tennis player [[Nikolay Davydenko]] from allegations that he fixed a match against [[Martin Vassallo Arguello]] in [[Poland]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Drape |first1=Joe |title=Inquiry into betting clears Davydenko |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/13/sports/tennis/13tennis.html |accessdate=July 27, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=September 12, 2008}}</ref> In 2016, an investigation found that several millions of dollars were placed on the match from Russian-based accounts. Leaked files to the joint [[Buzzfeed]] and [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] investigators found 82 instances were Davydenko had sent or received [[text message]]s from the suspected head of an [[Italy|Italian]] [[sports betting]] syndicate.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tennis investigation reportedly uncovers evidence of match-fixing by core group of 16 professional players |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-18/tennis-probe-uncovers-evidence-of-match-fixing-reports/7094546 |accessdate=27 July 2018 |work=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=17 January 2016}}</ref> * On 18 January 2016, a joint [[Buzzfeed]] and [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] investigation reported alleged widespread match-fixing, which involve Northern Italian, Sicilian, and Russian betting syndicates, which included suspicious betting at major tournaments such as [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]]. The reporters examined betting incidents on a total of 26,000 matches.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/35319202|title=Tennis match fixing: Evidence of suspected match-fixing revealed|date=18 January 2016|accessdate=21 January 2016|first=Simon|last=Cox|publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]]}}</ref> *In June 2018, [[Argentinian]] tennis player [[Nicolas Kicker]] was banned from the sport for at least three years for match-fixing. According to an investigation by the [[Tennis Integrity Unit]], Kicker knowingly participated in at least two matches in 2015. The ruling prohibits Kicker from competing in or attending a sanctioned tennis match.<ref>{{cite news |title=Nicolás Kicker Is Barred for at Least 3 Years for Match Fixing |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/19/sports/tennis/nicolas-kicker-suspended-match-fixing.html |accessdate=August 5, 2018 |work=The New York Times |agency=Associated Press |date=June 19, 2018}}</ref>
==Volleyball== *During the qualifying period for the [[2012 Summer Olympics]], the [[Japan women's national volleyball team]] came under scrutiny for allegedly throwing a match against [[Serbia women's national volleyball team|Serbia]] in order to get a better Olympic seeding. The [[Fédération Internationale de Volleyball]] cleared Japan in May 2012 and the team was allowed to compete in the Olympic Games.<ref>{{cite news |title=Japan's volleyball team cleared |url=http://www.espn.com/olympics/volleyball/story/_/id/7987315/japan-women-volleyball-cleared-fixing-2012-london-olympics-qualifier |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=ESPN.com |agency=Associated Press |date=May 30, 2012}}</ref> *In 2012, the [[Korea Volleyball Federation]] expelled four [[South Korea]]n volleyball players for life after its disciplinary panel found evidence they took part in fixing matches. A fifth player was suspected of being in on the fixes, but was not expelled due to limited evidence.<ref>{{cite news |title=Volleyball-Four Korean players get life ban for match-fixing |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/volleyball-korea-ban-idUKL4E8DD1Y820120213 |accessdate=26 July 2018 |work=Reuters |date=12 February 2012}}</ref> Later that year evidence from South Korean prosecutors would implicate 16 volleyball players involved in match-fixing schemes.<ref>{{cite news |title=16 South Korean volleyball, 2 baseball players indicted on match-fixing charges |url=http://zeenews.india.com/sports/others/16-south-korean-volleyball-2-baseball-players-indicted-on-match-fixing-charges_739198.html |accessdate=July 26, 2018 |work=Zee News |date=March 14, 2012}}</ref> *In 2016, [[Federation Internationale de Volleyball]] president [[Jizhong Wei]] released a statement following allegations by the [[Thailand women's national volleyball team|Thai women's national volleyball team]] that [[Japan women's national volleyball team|Japan]] had fixed an [[Summer Olympics|Olympic]] qualifying match. Wei said there was no evidence of match-fixing.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sakaowan |first1=Prae |title=Volleyball drama: Japan labeled 'cheaters' as victory over Thailand causes world outrage |url=https://coconuts.co/bangkok/news/volleyball-drama-japan-labeled-cheaters-victory-over-thailand-causes-world-outrage/ |accessdate=26 July 2018 |work=Coconuts Bangkok |date=19 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Match-fixing claim rejected by volleyball world body |url=https://www.rnw.org/archive/match-fixing-claim-rejected-volleyball-world-body |website=rnw.org |publisher=RNW Media |accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref>
