{{Use Australian English|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2011}} {{refimprove|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Graham Kennedy Show | image = | caption = | camera = | picture_format = 4.3 Black and White (1972-1975)
4.3 [[PAL]] (1975) | audio_format = [[Stereo]] | runtime = Approximately 60 minutes (inc. commercials) | creator = | developer = | executive_producer = | presenter = [[Graham Kennedy]] | starring = | country = [[Australia]] | language = English | network = [[Nine Network]] | first_aired = 19 September 1972 | last_aired = 17 April 1975 | num_seasons = 4 | num_episodes = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''The Graham Kennedy Show''''' was an [[Australia]]n talk show which debuted on 19 September 1972 on the [[Nine Network]]. On 23 December 1969, host [[Graham Kennedy]] quit as host of ''[[In Melbourne Tonight]]'' due to exhaustion and rested for two years. In spite of his fame and fortune, he later described that period as "years of misery".{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} After specials on 15 November 1971 and 2 March 1972, he returned with this series. Kennedy sparked controversy after a "crow-call", which sounded like the word "[[fuck]]", was broadcast in March 1975 (see below). Forced to prerecord from that point on, he abruptly departed following [[GTV-9]]'s censorship of the 16 April 1975 edition. ==Crow call incident== On the show of 3 March 1975, Kennedy imitated a crow, saying "faaaaaaark", during a live read of a Cedel hairspray advertisement by announcer Rosemary Margan. The [[Nine Network]] reportedly received hundreds of complaints, followed by a rash of newspaper headlines the next day. This led the [[Australian Broadcasting Control Board]] to request that Kennedy "show cause" why he should not be removed from the airwaves.{{cite news|title=Kennedy faces a total ban on TV|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XVoQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OpIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3156%2C949082|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=The Age (Melbourne)|date=1975-03-05|ref=1}} Kennedy replied that he could not show cause,{{cite news|title=Kennedy case to be heard on Tuesday|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=N_xjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=m-YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=904%2C3520849|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=1975-03-12|ref=2}}{{cite news|title=Order to Kennedy producer - threat to two TV shows|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MvxjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=m-YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3160%2C1897513|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=1975-03-07|ref=3}} suggesting that the Board take action to limit his appearances, while hinting at legal action should they do so.{{cite news|title=Court threat by Kennedy|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NvxjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=m-YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5757%2C3373285|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=1975-03-11|ref=4}} Rather than removing him, the ABCB banned Kennedy from appearing live, forcing him to pre-record the show on videotape.{{cite news|title=TV and radio ban on 'live' Kennedy|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PvxjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=m-YDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3781%2C4968719|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=1975-03-19|ref=5}} Some{{who|date=April 2014}} have claimed that Kennedy deliberately engineered the crow call incident so that the show would have to be prerecorded, allowing him to get home earlier, while others{{who|date=April 2014}} suggest that he did it so that Nine would sack him. In 2002, in ''[[The Age]]'' newspaper, writer [[Jonathan Green (journalist)|Jonathan Green]] reported that the crow call segment was in fact pretaped and that the controversy was probably just a pretext for other issues. Rival Nine personality [[Ernie Sigley]], who presented his own variety show on different nights to Kennedy, has claimed the real reason Kennedy was axed was that his ratings were so poor compared to Sigley's.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} According to ''Age'' reporter [[Suzanne Carbone]], the first known use of the expletive on Australian TV was in the 1960s, when Nine Adelaide evening news presenter [[Kevin Crease]] said "fucking hell" during a mishap in a live advertisement on variety show ''Adelaide Tonight''. Crease told ''The Age'' that "The audience fell off their chairs laughing" and that he was amazed no complaints were received and that although he feared he would be sacked, nothing happened. ==Criticism of Doug McClelland== Having been forced to tape his shows "indefinitely" by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, the network took advantage of the pretaping to completely [[censorship|edit out]] Kennedy's scathing attack on Senator [[Doug McClelland]], the then Minister for the Media, for his failure to support local content regulations for TV on the 16 April 1975 edition. According to Kennedy's biographer, [[Graeme Blundell]], Kennedy resigned from Nine after this controversy, just six weeks after the "crow call" incident. Kennedy's words which never made it to air were:
: Good evening. : Little serious bit to start with: Senator Douglas McClelland, ahh, is really copping it in the press at the moment. All this week, every paper you pick up, there's a, there's a roast of the Senator. : And like most Australians, I hate to kick a man when he's down. : (audience laughter) : But in Doug McClelland's case, I happily make an exception. : (audience laughter) : He has failed, and he knows it too. Now, the public know it. : This misguided Minister took credit for a mythical boom in television production. Now, there is no boom. : Employment in television production is down this year, by over 30 percent, and that's a fact. : His point system has proved utterly ineffective, and I wonder if you can remember who that little blond-headed fellow was, who works on television, who originally pointed out that it wouldn't work. : (audience: Graham!) : That's right. : (audience laughter) : We are all suffering from the lack of local content at the moment. I'm being thrashed in the surveys because constantly being thrown at, up against me are shows like the Academy Awards, imported films, and cheap television series, all purchased for a few hundred dollars from the Yanks. : Now some of these - when I say a few hundred dollars, by the time it's amortised over the network, that's how much the program costs. Now we can't compete, umm, with the price of these shows. : We cannot: this is a, what is this, a six thousand dollar a night ... uhh, we can play Mrs. Miniver for, err, ninepence. : (audience laughter) : It's beneath my dignity to even go into the laughable and inane carryings-on of the Australian Broadcasting Control Board which the good Minister of the Crown, Senator Douglas McClelland, is in charge of, but I know I can speak for a lot of my colleagues in this industry, and several other industries in the entertainment field, when I demand, here, tonight, nationally, that Senator McClelland be dismissed from office; and I would suggest most strongly that the portfol ... the portfolio itself be dropped. : That's all I want to say.
During a segment featuring guest [[Daryl Somers]], Kennedy said that he'd let it be known that Somers would make a suitable replacement host "... should I be on my way".https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rPfO4J8Fli8 In the first commercial break, Kennedy addressed the opening comments off-air with the studio audience, wondering if the network would cut the remarks, and stating that if they did, he would repeat them live on ''[[This Day Tonight]]''. He made the same threat on-air during the "wheel" segment later in the episode, with he and [[Bert Newton]] both effectively repeating the opening remarks. Kennedy also remarked that McClelland was "...not all that literate", and that "... he has to go". The opening segment was indeed edited out before the show went to air and Kennedy resigned in anger. He did not, however, follow through with the threat to repeat the comments on ''This Day Tonight'', with an ABC spokesman later commenting that Kennedy had decided that it "would not be in his interests" to appear.https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=R-BUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PZIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6737%2C3736612 Australian content on TV was a highly sensitive issue at this time. In the wake of the controversial [[McLean Report]], the [[Gough Whitlam|Whitlam]] government was taking major steps to open up the radio spectrum with the introduction of community broadcasting and the ABC's new rock station, [[Triple J]] (launched as "Double Jay"), but it had done nothing to address the low levels of local content on Australian TV. Aware of the media's crucial role in its own election in 1972, and understandably fearful of a backlash if it forced unpopular content quotas on the industry, the government steered well clear of any serious re-examination of the current structure and did little to increase levels of Australian content on TV. The proposal to increase local content had long been advocated local producers, writers and actors, but it was bitterly opposed by the networks, who relied on being able to buy large blocks of American programming at a fraction of what it would have cost to produce similar shows locally. The problem was compounded by the Whitlam government's far-reaching 1973 decision to reduce [[tariff]]s across the board by 25% in the first move towards today's highly successful "free trade" policies. The immediate result of the tariff reduction was that overseas programming became even cheaper. Also at this time, the networks were being targeted by the "TV - Make It Australian" campaign, which involved a number of prominent Australian actors and TV personalities including Kennedy and several leading actors from the popular police shows made by [[Crawford Productions]], notably [[Gerard Kennedy (actor)|Gerard Kennedy]] and [[Charles Tingwell|Charles "Bud" Tingwell]]. The cancellation of all three major Crawford Productions police shows within months of each other during 1975 has been portrayed by Tingwell and others as an act of revenge by the networks for Crawford's active support for the campaign and the participation of its contract players. Following this logic, Blundell suggests that Kennedy too was a victim of the Nine TV network's sensitivity about the local content issue. It has also been suggested that, with a federal election looming, Nine used the crow call incident as a pretext to remove the politically vocal Kennedy, who was known to support the [[Australian Labor Party|ALP]]. ==Home media== Four episodes of ''The Graham Kennedy Show'' were released on DVD by [[Umbrella Entertainment]] in May 2013. The episodes include rare uncut footage.{{cite web|title=Umbrella Entertainment|url=http://www.umbrellaent.com.au/p-3604-graham-kennedy-show-the.aspx?|accessdate=19 July 2013}} == References == == External links == * {{YouTube|id=rPfO4J8Fli8|title="The Graham Kennedy Show", April 16 1975}} - the unedited McClelland comments which never went to air. {{DEFAULTSORT:Graham Kennedy Show, The}} [[Category:Australian television talk shows]] [[Category:Nine Network shows]] [[Category:Television shows set in Victoria (Australia)]] [[Category:1972 Australian television series debuts]] [[Category:1975 Australian television series endings]] [[Category:1970s Australian television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Black-and-white Australian television programs]] [[Category:Television controversies]]

{{Infobox film | name = The King of Kong | image = King of kong.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Seth Gordon]] | producer = {{Plain list | * [[Ed Cunningham]] * Luis Lopez * J. Clay Tweel * Beau Bauman * Ross Tuttle }} | writer = | narrator = | starring = {{Plain list | * [[Steve Wiebe]] * [[Billy Mitchell (video game player)|Billy Mitchell]] * [[Walter Day]] * [[Brian Kuh]] * [[Todd Rogers (video game player)|Todd Rogers]] * Steve Sanders * [[Doris Self]] }} | music = Craig Richey | cinematography = Ross Tuttle | editing = {{plainlist| * Jim Bruce * J. Clay Tweel }} | distributor = [[Picturehouse (company)|Picturehouse]]
Dendy Cinemas | released = {{film date|2007|08|17}} | runtime = 79 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $790,128{{cite web |title= The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters |url= http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=kingofkong.htm |work= [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate= 28 February 2012}} }} '''''The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters''''' is a 2007 American [[documentary film]] about [[competitive gaming]] directed by [[Seth Gordon]]. It follows [[Steve Wiebe]] in his attempts to take the [[high score]] record for the 1981 arcade game ''[[Donkey Kong (video game)|Donkey Kong]]'' from the previous holder, [[Billy Mitchell (video game player)|Billy Mitchell]]. The film premiered at the [[2007 Slamdance Film Festival]] and was released in US theaters in August 2007. It received positive reviews. ==Summary== [[Walter Day]] is the founder of [[Twin Galaxies]], an organization dedicated to tracking [[Score (game)|high scores]] in [[arcade game]]s. Among the high-scoring players is restaurateur [[Billy Mitchell (video game player)|Billy Mitchell]], who has held the high score for the 1981 game ''[[Donkey Kong (video game)|Donkey Kong]]'' since 2004. In [[Redmond, Washington]], out-of-work engineer [[Steve Wiebe]] has purchased a ''Donkey Kong'' cabinet to try to break the record. Using his mathematical knowledge to identify exploitable patterns in the game, Wiebe achieves a new record of 1,006,600 points – the first ever score over a million. He submits a tape to Twin Galaxies, which propels him to local celebrity in the Seattle area. Mitchell and Twin Galaxies send two referees to investigate Wiebe's machine. They learn that the machine's [[Printed circuit board|circuit board]] was provided by Roy Shildt, a self-proclaimed fitness guru and [[pickup artist]] who claims the high score for ''[[Missile Command]]''. Unbeknownst to Wiebe, Shildt and Mitchell have been at odds for years after Mitchell questioned Shildt's high score, causing Twin Galaxies to disqualify it. Twin Galaxies suspects that Shildt may have tampered with Wiebe's board, and does not recognize Wiebe's record. Wiebe travels to a tournament at [[Funspot Family Fun Center|Funspot]] in [[Laconia, New Hampshire]], to attempt a live high score for high-ranking Twin Galaxies members. Wiebe challenges Mitchell to a ''Donkey Kong'' competition, but Mitchell does not attend. Before a crowd, Wiebe sets a new high score of 985,600 and reaches the [[kill screen]], ending the game. However, contrary to his statements that videotaped scores carry less validity than scores achieved in public, Mitchell sends a low-quality VHS to Funspot depicting himself achieving a higher score of 1,047,200 points. Twin Galaxies proclaims Mitchell the record holder. Nine months later, ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' has decided to publish Twin Galaxies' records — including Mitchell's latest score – and hosts a tournament in Mitchell's hometown of [[Hollywood, Florida]]. Wiebe again challenges Mitchell to a public competition, but Mitchell refuses. Wiebe fails to surpass the record, but afterward, Day acknowledges Wiebe's integrity and invites him to submit taped scores. At home, Wiebe achieves a new record of 1,049,100 in his garage. ==Appearances== * [[Steve Wiebe]], the challenger * [[Billy Mitchell (video game player)|Billy Mitchell]], described in the film as "the world's best gamer" * [[Walter Day]], the founder of [[Twin Galaxies]] * Robert Mruczek, the chief referee of Twin Galaxies * Brian Kuh, friend of Billy Mitchell and ''Donkey Kong'' player * Steve Sanders, friend of Billy Mitchell and ''Donkey Kong'' player * Dwayne Richard, classic gaming World Champion * Roy Shildt (aka "Mr. Awesome"), Billy Mitchell's "[[Archenemy|nemesis]]" * [[Todd Rogers (electronic sports player)|Todd Rogers]] * Greg Bond, ''[[Mappy]]'' champion * [[Doris Self]], previous holder of the ''[[Q*bert]]'' record and title of oldest game champion * Wiebe Family == Release == ''The King of Kong'' premiered January 22, 2007, at the [[2007 Slamdance Film Festival|Slamdance Film Festival]][https://web.archive.org/web/20071016074956/http://slamdance.com/2007/festival/film_detail.asp?film_id=994 The King of Kong - Slamdance Film Festival 2007]. Slamdance.com. Retrieved 2007-08-26. and has been shown at the [[Newport Beach Film Festival]], the [[Seattle International Film Festival]], the [[SXSW Film Festival]], the [[TriBeCa Film Festival]], the [[True/False Film Festival]], the [[Aspen Comedy Festival]], and the [[Fantasia Festival]]. The film opened in [[limited release]] in the United States on August 17, 2007 in five theaters, and by September 9, 2007, it had expanded to 39 theaters.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekend&id=kingofkong.htm|title=The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007) - Weekend Box Office|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=2007-09-12}} The film's [[DVD]] release was on January 29, 2008.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} ==Reception== {{Anchor|Critical response}} On [[Metacritic]], ''The King of Kong'' has an average score of 83 out of 100, based on 23 reviews.{{cite web | url= http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/kingofkong | title = King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters, The (2007): Reviews | accessdate = 2 October 2016 |publisher= [[CBS Interactive]] | work = [[Metacritic]] |archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070825225712/http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/kingofkong| dead-url= yes | archivedate =2007-08-25}} On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], it has a score of 97% based on 99 reviews.{{cite web | url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/king_of_kong/ | title = The King Of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters | work = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher = [[Flixster]] | accessdate = 2008-08-22 }} Robert Wilonsky of the ''[[Village Voice]]'' called the film a "miniature masterpiece"{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/film/0733,wilonsky,77508,20.html |title=Tracking Shots: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters |accessdate=2007-08-26 |author=Robert Wilonsky |date=2007-08-14 |publisher=[[Village Voice]]}} and in August 2007 said it was his favourite film of the year so far.{{cite web|url=http://kplusb.org/ebertroeper/all-title.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120223416/http://kplusb.org/ebertroeper/all-title.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-11-20 |title=Ebert & Roeper - August 17, 2007 episode |accessdate=2007-09-12 |date=2007-08-17 |publisher=[[At the Movies with Ebert & Roeper|Ebert & Roeper]] }} Pete Vonder Haar of [[Film Threat]] gave the film five stars and said "It’s not just one of the best documentaries I’ve ever seen, it’s one of the best movies I’ve ever seen".{{cite web|url=http://www.filmthreat.com/index.php?section=reviews&Id=9866 |title=THE KING OF KONG |accessdate=2007-08-26 |author=Pete Vonder Haar |date=2007-08-18 |publisher=[[Film Threat]]}} Keith Phipps of ''[[The Onion]]'' [[The A.V. Club|AV Club]] gave the film an "A-" and said it was "a film about what it takes to make it in America."{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/content/cinema/the_king_of_kong_a_fistful_of |title=The King Of Kong: A Fistful Of Quarters |accessdate=2007-08-26 |author=Keith Phipps |date=2007-08-17 |publisher=''[[The Onion]]'' [[The A.V. Club|AV Club]]}} Peter Travers of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, writing: "Who would have guessed that a documentary about gamers obsessed with scoring a world record at ''Donkey Kong'' would not only be roaringly funny but serve as a metaphor for the decline of Western civilization?"{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/14137645/review/15807945/the_king_of_kong |title=The King of Kong : Review : ''Rolling Stone'' |accessdate=2007-08-26 |author=Peter Travers |date=2007-08-07 |publisher=Rolling Stone}} [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' similarly gave the film three out of four and called it "a documentary that is beyond strange."Ebert, Roger. [http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/the-king-of-kong-a-fistful-of-quarters-2007 "Review: 'THE KING OF KONG: A FISTFUL OF QUARTERS'."] ''Chicago Sun-Times'', August 23, 2007. Retrieved: June 29, 2017. Critic [[Richard Roeper]] stated that the film "deserves an Oscar nomination for Best Documentary" in 2007 on ''[[At the Movies (1986 TV program)|At The Movies]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_bfGz7ME4ME|title=At the Movies- King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)|date=2010-08-10|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=2013-02-14}} Ann Hornaday of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote: "Is there anything more tiresome than watching people play video games?" and "The competition is so vicious because the stakes are so low."{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/gog/movies/the-king-of-kong-a-fistful-of-quarters,1136090.html |title=The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters |accessdate=2007-08-26 |author=Ann Hornaday |date=2007-08-24 |publisher=The Washington Post}} Stephen Garrett of ''[[Time Out New York]]'' called it "moderately entertaining and ultimately kind of pathetic" and felt the early-1980s arcade subculture is explored in greater depth in the documentary ''[[Chasing Ghosts: Beyond the Arcade]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/84336/The_King_of_Kong-A_Fistful_of_Quarters.html |title=The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters |accessdate=2007-08-26 |author=Stephen Garrett |date=August 16–22, 2007 |publisher=Time Out New York Issue 620 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116121305/http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/84336/The_King_of_Kong-A_Fistful_of_Quarters.html |archivedate=2013-01-16 |df= }} {{Anchor|Awards|Accolades}} The North Texas Film Critics Association named ''The King of Kong'' Best Documentary for 2007.{{cite news |first=John P. |last=Meyer |newspaper=Pegasus News |location=[[Dallas, TX]] |title=North Texas Film Critics Association picks the best of 2007 |url=https://imdb.com/event/ev0001982/2007/1/ |date=January 17, 2008 |accessdate=December 21, 2012 }} The [[Boston Society of Film Critics]] named it the runner-up for Best Documentary Feature of 2007.{{cite web |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |title=Metacritic: 2007 Film Awards & Nominations |url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2007/awardsandnominations.shtml |accessdate=January 8, 2008 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071231214824/http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2007/awardsandnominations.shtml |archivedate=2007-12-31}} It was nominated for Best Documentary Feature of 2007 by the [[Broadcast Film Critics Association]]. The film was also nominated for Best Documentary Feature by the [[Chicago Film Critics Association]], but lost to ''[[Sicko]]''. It appeared on several critics' top ten lists of the best films of 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2007/toptens.shtml|title=Metacritic: 2007 Film Critic Top Ten Lists|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080223094629/http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2007/toptens.shtml |archivedate=2008-02-23|accessdate=2008-02-25}} ==Emulation controversy== On February 2, 2018, Twin Galaxies member Jeremy Young filed a complaint regarding several of Mitchell's records.Alexandra, Heather (February 7, 2018). [https://kotaku.com/billy-mitchell-breaks-silence-about-donkey-kong-high-sc-1822815818 "Billy Mitchell Breaks Silence About ''Donkey Kong'' High Score Controversy"]. [[Kotaku]]. The validity of Mitchell's August 7, 2010, high score, set at Boomers-Grand Prix Arcade, could not be determined. The referee who allegedly witnessed and certified the record was gamer [[Todd Rogers (video game player)|Todd Rogers]], who appears in ''The King of Kong'', and was himself exposed as having fabricated scores earlier in 2018.Orland, Kyle (February 8, 2018). [https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2018/02/king-of-kong-star-says-original-tape-will-prove-his-disputed-scores "''King of Kong'' star says 'original tape' will prove his disputed scores"]. [[Ars Technica]]. On April 12, Twin Galaxies announced that Mitchell had used [[Emulator|emulation software]] to achieve the ''Donkey Kong'' high score rather than an arcade machine; this is banned because it allows players to cheat in undetectable ways. Mitchell was stripped of his records and banned from submitting further scores, and Wiebe was recognized as the first person to score over a million points. Footage obtained from the ''Kong'' DVD's special features was cited by the investigative committee in their findings as having been instrumental in exposing Mitchell.Crecente, Brian (April 12, 2018). [https://variety.com/2018/gaming/news/king-of-kong-stripped-of-title-1202751358/ "Famed Donkey Kong Player Stripped of Title"]. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. ==Adaptations and sequels== In 2014, ''King of Kong: The Musical'', which parodied the characters and events depicted in the documentary began its limited run.{{cite web|url=https://www.kingofkongthemusical.com|title=King of Kong the Musical|website=www.kingofkongthemusical.com|accessdate=26 January 2018}} A scripted film adaptation is also in the works. Director [[Seth Gordon]] has said that the movie might be a sequel instead of a remake, telling the story of how the documentary changed both men's lives, as well as their continuing rivalry.[http://www.justpressplay.net/articles/1863-king-of-kong-movie-might-be-a-sequel-nathan-fillion-vs-johnny-depp.html 'King of Kong' Movie Might Be a Sequel? Nathan Fillion vs Johnny Depp?] JustPressPlay. August 27, 2007. Retrieved April 13, 2018. ==See also== * [[Golden age of arcade video games]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120316030444/http://www.billyvssteve.com/ Official website] * {{IMDb title|0923752}} * {{Amg movie|384804}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|king_of_kong}} * {{metacritic film|the-king-of-kong-a-fistful-of-quarters}} * {{mojo title|kingofkong}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071016074956/http://slamdance.com/2007/festival/film_detail.asp?film_id=994 ''The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters''] at slamdance.com * [https://www.apple.com/trailers/picturehouse/kingofkong/ Trailer] at [[Apple Inc|Apple.com]] * [http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/read.php?ID=30569 ''King of Kong''] at DVDtalk.com * {{YouTube|6b-QK8TxeXk|Steve Wiebe tells movie goers not to talk during the movie}} * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216195739/http://www.ignoremagazine.com/features/sethgordon/index.php |date=February 16, 2009 |title=In depth article/interview from ''Ignore Magazine''}} {{Donkey Kong series}} {{Seth Gordon}} {{Donkey Kong high score competition}} {{DEFAULTSORT:King Of Kong, The: Fistful Of Quarters}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Donkey Kong]] [[Category:Documentary films about video games]] [[Category:Documentary films about competitions]] [[Category:Films directed by Seth Gordon]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:ESports films]] [[Category:Picturehouse films]] [[Category:Documentary films about fandom]] [[Category:Video game controversies]]

September 18, 2017 | genre = [[Survival horror|Survival]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} '''''The Solus Project''''' is a [[First person (video games)|first-person]] [[Single-player video game|single-player]] [[Survival game|survival]] video game developed by [[Teotl Studios]] and [[Grip Games]]. An [[early access]] version of the game was released on [[Steam (software)|Steam]], [[Xbox One]] and [[GOG.com|GOG]] in February 2016, and the full version of the game was released on June 7, 2016 on PC and July 15, 2016 for Xbox One .{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/play-xbox-one-and-pc-survival-game-the-solus-proje/1100-6434446/|title=Play Xbox One and PC Survival Game The Solus Project This Month|last=Te|first=Zorine|work=[[GameSpot]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|date=February 4, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016}} The game is a spiritual successor{{cite web| url=http://www.thesolusproject.com/#WhatIsSolus | title=The Solus Project - What Is Solus?}} to previous Teotl title, ''[[The Ball (video game)|The Ball]]''. == Gameplay == ''The Solus Project'' is an advanced environmental survival-adventure game, in which the player controls an astronaut on a mission to save mankind. Their spacecraft crashes on an uncharted, alien planet, Gliese-6143-C. They have to survive on the planet and faces factors such as hunger level, thirst, body temperature or weather conditions. The player explores the planet full of temples and other interesting places.{{cite web|url=http://www.gameskinny.com/o53z8/the-solus-project-is-out-to-test-your-survival-skills|title=The Solus Project is out to test your survival skills|last1=Hossain|first1=Manisha|work=GameSkinny|publisher=Guild Launch, LLC|date=June 20, 2015|accessdate=July 16, 2015}} Your character is the lone survivor of a crew looking for a colony, as mankind is on the verge of extinction. Plants grow and rot, weather changes from scorching heat to chilling storms, and the wind and humidity are unforgiving. Craft items, explore vast areas, monitor your health, sleep regularly and more. Learn the secrets of a mysterious alien civilization that might hold the key to mankind's survival. ==Reception== The Solus Project has a score of 68, a "Mixed or Average" rating on Metacritic, based upon 27 reviews.http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/the-solus-project We Got This Covered awarded it a score of three and a half out of five stars, saying "Despite mechanical discord and an unsatisfying story, the creepy atmosphere and gargantuan spectacle of The Solus Project is worth experiencing firsthand."Holloway, Josh, "The Solus Project Review" (http://wegotthiscovered.com/gaming/the-solus-project-review/). We Got This Covered. Accessed June 10, 2016. The game has currently received a four star rating on [[GOG.com]]{{cite web|url=https://www.gog.com/game/the_solus_project|title=The Solus Project - GOG.com|access-date=June 13, 2016}} and a 'Very Positive' rating on [[Steam (software)|Steam]].{{cite web|url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/313630/|title=The Solus Project - Steam|access-date=June 13, 2016}} The Solus Project has 3 nominations for [[Czech Game of the Year Awards]]. It is nominated in categories Best audio, Best story and Best visuals.{{cite web|title=Nominace - ČESKÁ HRA ROKU 2016|url=http://ceskahraroku.cz/nominace-2016/|website=ČESKÁ HRA ROKU 2016|accessdate=January 28, 2017|language=cs-CZ}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *{{Official website|http://www.thesolusproject.com/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Solus Project}} [[Category:Early access video games]] [[Category:Indie video games]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:Science fiction video games]] [[Category:Survival video games]] [[Category:Unreal Engine games]] [[Category:2016 video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Sweden]] [[Category:Video games developed in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox One games]]

'''Theatre studies''' (sometimes referred to as '''theatrology''' or '''dramatics''') is the study of theatrical performance in relation to its literary, physical, psycho-biological, sociological, and historical contexts. It is an interdisciplinary field which also encompasses the study of theatrical [[aesthetics]] and [[semiotics]].<ref>Helbo, André (1987). [https://books.google.com/books?id=55R9XVomHWIC&pg=PA37&dq=Theatrology&hl=en&ei=w6PgTfzIIsyq8APE-635Bg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Theatrology&f=false ''Theory of Performing Arts'']. John Benjamins Publishing Company, pp. 38-39. {{ISBN|90-272-2409-9}}</ref> A late 20th century development in the area has been the [[Ethnography|ethnographic]] theory of theatre, pioneered by the Russian scholar Larisa Ivleva (1944–1995) who studied the influence of folk culture on the development of Russian theatre.<ref>Galieva, Saule (1996). [https://books.google.com/books?id=qskJAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Theatrologist%22&dq=%22Theatrologist%22&hl=en&ei=3bbgTcSPH4el8QOg86yhBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBTgK ''Bulletin of the International Council for Traditional Music''], Issues 88-93, p. 33</ref><ref>Hill, John W. (2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=mImZk9lgIZAC&pg=PA58&dq=Larisa+Ivleva&hl=en&ei=N8DgTdnnGdO48gPc2eD8Bg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Larisa%20Ivleva&f=false "Comedian of the Seventeenth Century: Ostrovskii's Dialogue with Russian Theatre History"] in ''Text & Presentation, 2004'', Stratos E. Constantinidis (ed.). McFarland, pp. 58-59. {{ISBN|0-7864-2205-X}}</ref>
==List of theatrologists== [[File:Delsarte.jpg|thumb|130 px|French theatrologist [[François Delsarte]]]] Because of the interdisciplinary nature of the field, those who have been described as theatrologists can vary widely in terms of the primary focus of their activities. *[[Emil František Burian]]{{spaced ndash}}writer, singer, actor, musician, composer, playwright and director<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=FgUcAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Theatrologist%22&dq=%22Theatrologist%22&hl=en&ei=cc3gTemCJIKr8AO4royPBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAD ''Jazz Forum''] (1974). International Jazz Federation, p. 19</ref> *[[Jovan Ćirilov]]{{spaced ndash}}philosopher, [[Dramaturgy|dramaturge]], and writer *[[François Delsarte]]{{spaced ndash}}teacher of acting and singing<ref>Horton, Andrew (1993). [https://books.google.com/books?id=AYjOtWygMt0C&pg=PA67&dq=%22Theatrologist%22&hl=en&ei=mqvgTecXhdfyA8au1e4G&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFYQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22Theatrologist%22&f=false ''Inside Soviet Film Satire: Laughter with a lash'']. Cambridge University Press, p. 67. {{ISBN|0-521-43016-X}}</ref> *[[Joseph Gregor]]{{spaced ndash}}theatre historian and [[libretto|opera librettist]] *[[John Heilpern]]{{spaced ndash}}theatre critic and essayist<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=8MxZAAAAIAAJ&q=%22Theatrologist%22&dq=%22Theatrologist%22&hl=en&ei=mqvgTecXhdfyA8au1e4G&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA ''Polish art studies, Volume 3] (1982). Zakład Narodowy im. Ossolińskich, p. 333. {{ISBN|83-04-00936-6}}</ref> *[[Antoine Vitez]]{{spaced ndash}}actor, director, and poet<ref>Whitton, David (1995). [https://books.google.com/books?id=OszWLOBfTK4C&pg=PA170&dq=%22Theatrologist%22&hl=en&ei=mqvgTecXhdfyA8au1e4G&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFEQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22Theatrologist%22&f=false ''Molière, Don Juan'']. Cambridge University Press, p. 170. {{ISBN|0-521-47867-7}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Literary theory]] *[[Theatre criticism]] *[[Theatre practitioner]]

{{Infobox person |name = Ursula Schaeppi |other names = Ursula Schäppi |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1940|6|22}} |birth_place = [[Zürich]], [[Canton of Zürich]], [[Switzerland]] |death_date = |death_place = |occupation = Stage, television and film actress, playwright, comedian, radio personality |nationality = Swiss |spouse = Rudolf Haas |children = |years_active = since 1958 |residence = [[Thalwil]]<ref name="zsz-20150616">{{cite web|url=http://www.zsz.ch/horgen/Ursula-Schaeppi-wird-75-und-wechselt-von-Kindern-zu-Senioren/story/26559943|title=Ursula Schaeppi wird 75 und wechselt von Kindern zu Senioren|publisher=[[Zürichsee-Zeitung]]|author=|language=German|date=2015-06-16|accessdate=2015-08-28}}</ref> |notable_works = |awards = [[Ursula Schäppi#Awards]] }} '''Ursula Schaeppi''' or '''Ursula Schäppi''' (born 22 June 1940) is a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] comedian, radio personality, and stage, voice and film actress starring usually in Swiss German language stage productions and as voice actress in children's literature.
== Early life and education == Born and raised in [[Zürich]], [[Canton of Zürich]] in Switzerland, Ursula Schäppi began acting at the conservatory in Bern at Margarethe Schell von Noé in 1955 and in 1956/58 lessons with Walter Fried on ''Bühnenstudio Zürich'', and private lessons with Richard Münch. During her training Schaeppi premierred on stage, and played among others ''Gisèle'' in Giraudoux's "Intermezzo" on [[Schauspielhaus Zürich]] in 1955.<ref name="theaterlexikon-ursulaschäppi">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Ursula_Schaeppi|title=Ursula Schaeppi|author=Sonja Galler |language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-09-28}}</ref>
== Theater, playwright and children's literature and plays == In 1958 Schaeppi was engaged at the ''Studio 20'' in Bern as ''Laura'' in Williams' ''[[The Glass Menagerie]]''. From 1959 she worked at German city theaters, among other things, in Castorp-Rauxel, Berlin, München and in Rendsburg. At this time also began Schaeppi's career with children and trouser roles that later became one of her trademarks, including the title role in Saint-Exupéry's ''[[The Little Prince]]''. In 1968/69 she toured with the ''Deutsche Kammerspiele Buenos Aires'' through South and Central America, and received an engagement at ''Berliner Kammerspiele'' stages in 1971/72. Since 1969 she appeared in guest roles at Swiss theaters, for example, in 1969 at the ''Stadttheater Bern'' as ''Effie'' in Ludwig Thomas' "Moral", and in 1970 at the gallery theater ''Die Rampe'' in Bern as ''Mingo'' in the premiere of Alexander Ziegler's "Zellengeflüster". In 1976 she starred in the title role of [[Hansjörg Schneider]]'s "Sennentuntschi" that was directed by Schneider.<ref name="theaterlexikon-ursulaschäppi"/>
It was followed by appearances at the ''Stadttheater Luzern'', ''Kleintheater Kramgasse 6'' in Bern and at the ''Stadttheater Chur'', and since the early 1970s, also first appearances in the Swiss German dialect theater. Her breakthrough celebrated Ursula Schäppi in 1975,<ref name="theaterlexikon-ursulaschäppi"/><ref name="theaterlexikon-bernhard">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Bernhard-Theater,_Z%C3%BCrich_ZH|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|title=Bernhard-Theater, Zürich ZH|author=|language=German|date=2013-11-22|accessdate=2015-09-24}}</ref> at [[Bernhard-Theater Zürich]] as ''Heideli'' in the premiere of Max Rüeger's "Hochzeit in Hägglingen", under the direction of [[Inigo Gallo]],<ref name="theaterlexikon-gallo">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Inigo_Gallo|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|title=Inigo Gallo|author=|language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-09-24}}</ref> followed by regular appearances in the Bernhard-Theater, at first mainly in cabaret revues by [[Charles Lewinsky]],<ref name="theaterlexikon-lewinsky">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Charles_Lewinsky|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|title=Charles Lewinsky|author=Dietrich Seybold|language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-09-24}}</ref> Fredy Lienhard and [[Hans Gmür]], later in Swiss dialect versions of boulevard plays, for example, in 1988 in the title role of Jack Popplewell's successful play "Katharina die Kühne" and Swiss tour performances and television broadcasting. Moreover, Schaeppi created her own arrangements for Swiss productions of the Bernhard Theater where she also performed in leading roles. There, also the long-standing collaboration with Rudolf Haas and Franco Romano began. She had further guest appearances at other theaters, for example, in 1979 as ''Oma Zeitel'' in [[Jerry Bock]]'s musical "Anatevka" and in 1982 as ''Toinette '' in Molière's ''[[The Imaginary Invalid]]'' on ''Atelier Theater'' in Bern.<ref name="theaterlexikon-ursulaschäppi"/>
National merits gained Ursula Schäppi since 1977 through her appearances on Swiss television as ''Goof'' or ''Göre Ursula'' (cheeky girl) in Kurt Felix' "Teleboy", by her television show ''10 x Schaeppi'' and as ''Eva Chifler'' in "Traumpaar" with [[Walter Andreas Müller]] when even a song was listed in the Swiss radio charts.<ref name="chifler">{{cite web|url=http://hitparade.ch/album/Ursula-Schaeppi-und-Walter-Andreas-Mueller/Alp-Traum-Paar-Adam-&-Eva-Chifler-153747|publisher=hitparade.ch|title=Ursula Schaeppi und Walter Andreas Müller - Alp-Traum-Paar - Adam & Eva Chifler|author=|language=German|date=|accessdate=2015-09-28}}</ref> Starting in 1987, Schaeppi produced independent theater productions with Haas, Romano and Müller, in which she also starred and for which she often wrote the Swiss dialect versions, including in 1987 the Swiss premiere of Pierre Chesnot's "Vier linke Hände" with Müller and directed by Haas, in 1991 as "Käthi - Superstar", and in 1994 the dialect version of "Die Sternstunde der Hanna Bieder", which on ''Gastspieltheater Zürich'' was resumed in 2000. A great success was "Stan und Ollie in der Schweiz", starring Schaeppi as ''[[Stan Laurel|Stan]]'' and ''[[Stephanie Glaser]]'' as ''[[Oliver Hardy|Ollie]]''. Her productions staged for several years guest performances, among others at the Bernhard-Theater,<ref name="theaterlexikon-ursulaschäppi"/> on [[Theater am Hechtplatz]],<ref name="theaterlexikon-hechtplatz">{{cite web|url=http://tls.theaterwissenschaft.ch/wiki/Theater_am_Hechtplatz,_Z%C3%BCrich_ZH|publisher=theaterwissenschaft.ch|title=Theater am Hechtplatz, Zürich ZH|author=Tanja Stenzl|language=German|date=2013-12-05|accessdate=2015-09-26}}</ref> and on the studio stage of the [[Opernhaus Zürich]], at the ''Atelier-Theater'' in Bern and at the ''Sommertheater Winterthur''. After a long pause Schaeppi published other theater directing credits and Swiss dialect edits: in 1998 "Tatort: Goldküste!" according to Popplewell, and in 2001 the Swiss premiere of Jack Jacquin's "Der Mord zum Sonntag" on ''Gastspieltheater Zürich'' where Schaeppi starred in the lead role.<ref name="theaterlexikon-ursulaschäppi"/>
Ursula Schäppi wrote and spoke children's stories and fairy tales, which are available as audiobooks.<ref name="theaterlexikon-ursulaschäppi"/> She also became popular by numerous radio appearances. Beside the stage, she became popular, along with [[Jörg Schneider]], [[Paul Bühlmann]] and [[Ines Torelli]], by fairytale-radio plays records.<ref name="srf-archivperlen">{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/unterhaltung/people/schweiz/vip-archiv/archiv-perlen-die-schoensten-joerg-schneider-momente|title=Archiv-Perlen: Die schönsten Jörg-Schneider-Momente|publisher=[[Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen]] SRF|author=Karl Baldinger|language=German|date=2015-08-22|accessdate=2015-08-24}}</ref><ref name="zol-20150822">{{cite web|url=http://www.zol.ch/bezirk-hinwil/wetzikon/joerg-schneider-ist-tot/story/13778801|title=Jörg Schneider ist tot|publisher=[[Zürcher Oberländer]]|author=|language=German|date=2015-08-22|accessdate=2015-08-22}}</ref>
After many years absence from the stage, in 2012 she toured again in her signature role as ''Requisiteuse''. Ursula Schaeppi founded the children's theater studio in the [[Municipalities of the canton of Zürich|municipality]] of [[Thalwil]] on ''Zürichsee'' lake shore. Celebrating her 75th anniversary, Ursula Schaeppi announced to focus finally, at the request of a group of seniors, increasingly on theater productions with their peers because "many of the existing plays are just too dull".<ref name="zsz-20150616"/>
== Personal life == Ursula Schaeppi is a citizen of the [[Municipalities of the canton of Zürich|municipality]] of [[Thalwil]] in the [[Canton of Zürich]]. Schaeppi was married with Rudolf Haas, a Swiss and actor with whom she also toured. In 1998 on Swiss television SRF Schaeppi talked about her depression to which she suffered after seven friends died within a short period; it was accompanied by a career slump, and she stepped back public appearance.<ref name="zsz-20150616"/><ref name="srf">{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/radio-srf-musikwelle/radio-srf-musikwelle/ursula-schaeppi-nimmt-kein-blatt-vor-den-mund|title=Ursula Schaeppi nimmt kein Blatt vor den Mund|publisher=srf.ch|author=|language=German|date=2015-06-21|accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref> She also suffers of chronic lymphoid leukaemia which did not to allow to stage again on [[Bernhard-Theater Zürich]] in "Sie spillt wieder mit öis. Aber nume no eimal!".<ref name="si">{{cite web|url=http://www.schweizer-illustrierte.ch/stars/schweiz/die-schauspielerin-hat-krebs|title=Die Schauspielerin hat Krebs|publisher=schweizer-illustrierte.ch|author=|language=German|date=2013-04-21|accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref>

https://www.threenow.co.nz/shows/westside-s3/S1308-818 | website_title = Official website | production_website = http://westsidetv.co.nz/ }} '''''Westside''''' is a New Zealand [[comedy-drama]] television series created by Rachel Lang and James Griffin{{cite news|last=Jenkin|first=Lydia|title=Westside: Outrageous Fortune rewinds the clock|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=11451772|accessdate=3 June 2015|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=24 May 2015}} for [[South Pacific Pictures]]. It is a prequel to ''[[Outrageous Fortune (TV series)|Outrageous Fortune]]'', and chronicles the lives of Ted and Rita West. The first series aired from 31 May to 5 July 2015 on [[Three (New Zealand)|Three]]. Series 4 premiered on 9 July 2018.{{cite web|title=The new series of #WestsideTV premieres on Monday July 9th at 8:30pm on Three.|url=https://www.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=10156567480892360&id=137039682359&__tn__=-R|publisher=Outrageous Fortune & Westside on Facebook|accessdate=25 June 2018|date=23 June 2018}} On 21 July 2018 [[NZ on Air]] announced funding for a fifth series which will consist of 10 episodes.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nzonair.govt.nz/news/three-powerful-real-life-dramas-tv-audiences-and-favourite-returns/|title=Three powerful real-life dramas for TV audiences and a favourite returns|website=[[NZ on Air]]|language=en|access-date=21 July 2018}} == Plot == The first series is set in the 1970s, it features a [[Westie (person)|Westie]] couple, and stars [[Antonia Prebble]] and [[David de Lautour]] as Rita and Ted West. In the first episode, set in 1974, it features [[John Walker (runner)|John Walker]] beating [[Rod Dixon]] in the 1500 metres at the [[1974 Commonwealth Games]]. Each episode covers one year, from 1974 to 1979, with events like the Muldoon election, dawn raids on overstayers, carless days, and the birth of the punk rock scene in Auckland.{{cite news|title=TV picks: Westside, the Outrageous Fortune prequel|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/entertainment/news/article.cfm?c_id=1501119&objectid=11456184|accessdate=3 June 2015|work=The New Zealand Herald|date=31 May 2015}} The second series is set in 1981, and follows the [[1981 South Africa rugby union tour|Springbok Tour]]. The series starts with Rita returning home from prison to find the West household in disrepair. Throughout the course of the series Ted's gang plots to steal from the South Africans visiting New Zealand, preventing them from buying land, while Rita plans a job against developer Evan Lace. The third Series is set in 1982 and deals with the fallout from the Evan Lace job and Wolf's first meeting with his future wife, Cheryl. == Cast and characters == This table shows the show's characters and the cast members who have portrayed them. {{essay-like|date=September 2013}} [[File:Grasshopper on Prairie Grass.JPG|thumb]]
'''Zoopoetics''' has been defined as "the process of discovering innovative breakthroughs in form through an attentiveness to another species' bodily ''poiesis''." It assumes many actual, biological animals possess agency to craft gestures, vocalizations—clear material signs—in order to create social cohesion with conspecifics and other animals.<ref>{{cite book|last=Moe|first=Aaron|title=Zoopoetics: Animals and the Making of Poetry|year=2014|publisher=Lexington Books|location=Lanham|isbn=978-0-7391-8662-6|pages=10, 19–22|url=https://rowman.com/ISBN/9780739186626}}</ref>
Zoopoetics is not a minor event in poetry, nor is it limited to human spheres. Other species discover innovative forms of their bodily ''[[poiesis]]'', through, at times, an attentiveness towards humans. Many disciplines have contributed to the radical revaluation of the animal in culture and society; zoopoetics further contributes through tracing the implications of [[Walt Whitman|Whitman]]’s insight, that animals, including humans, follow the “same old law” of a bodily ''poiesis''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Whitman|first=Walt|title=Poetry and Prose|year=1982|publisher=The Library of America|location=New York|pages=199}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Moe|first=Aaron|title=Toward Zoopoetics: Rethinking Whitman's 'original energy'|journal=Walt Whitman Quarterly Review|year=2013|volume=31|issue=1|pages=1–17|url=http://ir.uiowa.edu/wwqr/vol31/iss1/2/|doi=10.13008/0737-0679.2091}}</ref>
== Usage == [[Jacques Derrida]] first used the term in ''The Animal that Therefore I Am'' (an address first delivered in 1997), speaking of “Kafka’s vast zoopoetics.”<ref>{{cite book|last=Derrida|first=Jacques|title=The Animal that Therefore I Am|year=2007|publisher=Fordham UP|location=New York|pages=6|translator=David Wills |editor=Marie-Louise Mallet}}</ref> And so, in the broadest sense, zoopoetics suggests the presence of nonhuman animals within a text. In a 2008 dissertation, Christopher White establishes another facet of zoopoetics by conflating it with the term [[zoosemiotics]] (the sign-systems of nonhuman animals), and he uses both terms to explore the presence and sign-systems of animals in William Faulkner’s ''As I Lay Dying''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=White|first=Christopher|title=Dissertation|journal=Animals, Technology, and the Zoopoetics of American Modernism|year=2008|pages=115}}</ref>
Another facet of zoopoetics is explored in “Zoopoetics: A Look at [[E. E. Cummings|Cummings]], [[W. S. Merwin|Merwin]], & the Expanding Field of Ecocriticism.” Here, zoopoetics is more of an approach that “gravitates to the agency of nonhuman animals” within both the ecosphere and within texts. The notion of animal agency is defined by how nonhuman animals are imaginative, [[Rhetoric|rhetorical]], and cultural beings.<ref name=moe>{{cite journal|last=Moe|first=Aaron|title=Zoopoetics: Cummings, Merwin, & the Expanding Field of Ecocriticism|journal=Humanimalia: A Journal of Human/Animal Interface Studies|year=2012|volume=3|issue=2|url=http://www.depauw.edu/site/humanimalia/issue%206/moe.html}}</ref> The essay draws upon the well-known rhetorician George Kennedy, who published a controversial article in 1992: “A Hoot in the Dark: The Evolution of General Rhetoric.” In it, Kennedy argues that all animals, human and nonhuman, “share a ‘deep’ universal rhetoric.”<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kennedy|first=George|title=A Hoot in the Dark: The Evolution of General Rhetoric|journal=Philosophy and Rhetoric|year=1992|volume=25|issue=1|pages=6}}</ref> This rhetoric is not founded on sign-systems but rather upon what he calls the “rhetorical energy” of the gestures that deliver those sign-systems. Animals (including humans) constantly navigate rhetorical situations by delivering gestures to an audience with a specific purpose. Kennedy’s article challenged one of the long-standing assumptions concerning the difference between humans and animals, for he sees language as less of a distinguishing mark of human exceptionality and more of a commonality given the evolutionary origin shared by many animals. (For a recapitulation of the history of the response to Kennedy's article, as well as a defense of the ideas within it, see Debra Hawhee's "Toward a Bestial Rhetoric."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hawhee|first=Debra|title=Toward a Bestial Rhetoric|journal=Philosophy and Rhetoric|year=2011|volume=44|issue=1|pages=81–87|doi=10.1353/par.2011.0007}}</ref>)
Aaron Moe's book ''Zoopoetics: Animals and the Making of Poetry'' explores the zoopoetic dynamic in the poetry of Whitman, Cummings, Merwin, Hillman as well as several other poets.
As with many literary terms, it is helpful to look at the term’s etymology. Zoopoetics, etymologically speaking, has to do with how animals (''zoo'') can be capable of creation, or of "making" (''poesis''). Zoopoetics is seen as the process by which animal rhetorics may contribute to the making and shaping of both a specific poem as well as the overall poetics of a given author.<ref name=moe2>[http://aaronmoe.wordpress.com/2012/03/21/zoopoetics-revisited/ Moe, Aaron. (2012, March 21). "Zoopoetics Revisited" (blog post)]</ref>
One premise underlying zoopoetics is the notion that humans are not the only beings who dwell ([[Heideggerian terminology#Lichtung|in Heideggerian sense]]) on the earth. Nonhuman animals do as well. Some human poetry hints at the dwelling of the animal, but for obvious reasons, such an endeavor is fraught with challenges. Jacques Derrida articulates this challenge most clearly through his term limitrophy:
[[File:Carduelis pinus at feeder.jpg|thumb]] :''Limitrophy'' is therefore my subject. Not just because it will concern what sprouts or grows at the limit, around the limit, by maintaining the limit, but also what feeds the limit, generates it, raises it, and complicates it. Everything I'll say will consist, certainly not in effacing the limit, but in multiplying its figures, in complicating, thickening, delinearizing, folding, and dividing the line precisely by making it increase and multiply. . . . [The limit] has an abyss: The discussion is worth undertaking once it is a matter of determining the number, form, sense, or structure, the foliated consistency, of this abyssal limit, these edges, this plural and repeatedly folded frontier.<ref>{{cite book|last=Derrida|first=Jacques|title=The Animal that Therefore I Am|year=2008|publisher=Fordham UP|location=New York|pages=29–30|translator=David Wills |editor=Marie-Louise Mallet}}</ref>
The limit between the human and the animal becomes its own infinite terrain within the text, but Derrida seems to have overlooked one crucial aspect. It is not just the human who strives to venture into the abyss of the animal—reaching with language and with gestures—for animals also strive to venture into the abyss of the human through their gestures and the vocalizations embedded within those gestures. Stephanie Rowe demonstrates what this ebb and flow encounter may look like in a text. In her article, Rowe explores how the orangutang in Poe's story reaches into the abyss of the human, seeking to change the human space into a shared space. This occurs when the orangutang—a species whose culture is oft defined by grooming—takes on the human ritual of shaving. His gestures are misunderstood, of course, which has morbid consequences.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rowe|first=Stephanie|title=No Human Hand? The Ourang-Outang in Poe's 'The Murders in the Rue Morgue,' in Animals and Agency: An Interdisciplinary Exploration|publisher=Brill|location=Boston|pages=107–128|editor=Sarah E. McFarland |editor2=Ryan Hediger}}</ref>
Zoopoetics, then, is an ebb and flow of energy between the human and the nonhuman. The human reaches into the abyss of the animal, but acknowledges the animals reach as well. Perhaps zoopoetics can best be experienced in a poetics that allows the gestures and vocalizations of nonhuman animals to permeate human language, through [[iconicity]], thereby creating a shared space.<ref name=moe />
== Animal texts == [[File:Deer in Woods.jpg|thumb]]
Within literary studies, there is a movement toward a multiculturalism that includes the social networks of nonhuman animals.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Feder|first=Helena|title=Rethinking Multiculturalism: Theory and Nonhuman Cultures|journal=Interdisciplinary Studies in Literature and Environment|year=2010|volume=17|issue=4|pages=775–777}}</ref> For this to happen, though, humans must take seriously the notion that animals enter into rhetorical situations, crafting their own texts, for audiences, with specific purposes. The last thirty years of studies in animal behavior<ref>{{cite book|last=Laland|first=Kevin N. and Bennet G. Galef|title=The Question of Animal Culture|year=2009|publisher=Harvard UP|location=Cambridge}}</ref> have, in part, influenced the proliferation of video documentary of animals crafting such texts. For instance, ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20120203113419/http://dsc.discovery.com/videos/planet-earth-ice-worlds-humpback-hunt.html Planet Earth]'' captures several humpback whales coordinating efforts to surround krill with bubbles from their blowholes. As the video unfolds, viewers hear and witness the text the humpback whales craft. One can then infer that such behavior is learned, socially passed on from one generation of humpback to another. One can further infer that a single humpback, or a group of humpbacks, collectively had an innovative breakthrough in using the bubbles as a tool. This innovation had to be communicated to other humpbacks, and when this happens, the humpback enters into a rhetorical situation, relying on the text of song and gesture to communicate.
Orca also craft texts. Ethologists have recognized that such texts help maintain group cohesion,<ref>{{cite book|last=Sargeant|first=Brooke L. and Janet Mann|title=The Question of Animal Culture|year=2009|publisher=Harvard UP|location=Cambridge|pages=161|editor=Kevin N. Laland |editor2= Bennet G. Galef|chapter=From Social Learning to Culture: Intrapopulation Variation in Bottlenose Dolphins}}</ref> and they may therefore exemplify how animal texts sustain nonhuman animal cultures. For a live feeds of orca vocalizations (and archives of past recordings) from the Puget Sound, listen to [http://orcasound.net/lk/ this hydrophone].
A wide range of animals demonstrate similar crafting of texts, but to take this seriously, one must wrestle with the implications of how nonhuman animals enter rhetorical situations.
